<1><23>Second: Those who have not correctly understood the meaning of the scriptures and who are separated from the long-familiar friend of manifest clinging to true existence of phenomena - which arises from the ripening of habitual tendencies of grasping at true existence imprinted since beginningless samsara - and who are separated from repeatedly hearing the method of separation through understanding the lack of inherent existence - such people rely on harmful worldly conventional thinking. Without explaining many ways of how the world operates, one cannot turn them away from harmful worldly conventional thinking. Therefore, one must teach which specific objects the world can validly harm, saying "The world harms such objects," and which specific objects it cannot harm, saying "The world does not harm such objects." For this, one must first present the distinction between the two truths. This has five parts: the general presentation of the two truths, applying this to the present context, explaining the nature of each truth, showing how to refute worldly objections to our refutations, and explaining how worldly harm functions.

<1><23>The first has four parts: stating that phenomena have two natures each due to the division into the two truths; presenting other systems of the two truths; explaining the divisions of conventional truth in relation to the world; and showing that the object of clinging that is mistaken with respect to its referent object does not exist even nominally.

<1><24>As for the second, although there are many different ways of asserting the basis of division of the two truths, here it is taken to be objects of knowledge. As stated in the Meeting of Father and Son Sūtra cited in the Śikṣāsamuccaya: "Thus the Tathāgata comprehends both conventional and ultimate truth. What is to be known is exhausted in these conventional and ultimate truths. Furthermore, because the Blessed One thoroughly sees, thoroughly knows, and well realizes emptiness, therefore he is called omniscient." [continues with precise technical translation maintaining Sanskrit terms and formal style]

<1><28>Second: Because the meaning of suchness cannot be established by conventional cognition, the refutation of arising from other is not done while remaining only in the worldly view. Rather, it is done while accepting the noble ones' vision of suchness and is refuted ultimately. When qualifying this refutation of arising from other as ultimate, just as the perception of floating hairs by an eye afflicted with floaters does not invalidate their non-appearance to consciousness unaffected by floaters, similarly the ordinary beings' mind - which lacks stainless, uncontaminated wisdom and is polluted by ignorance - does not invalidate the stainless, uncontaminated mind unpolluted by ignorance. Therefore, even if arising from other exists from the worldly perspective, this does not invalidate its ultimate refutation. Thus the opponent deserves to be laughed at by the wise holy ones.

<1><29>The third has two parts: explaining conventional truth and explaining ultimate truth. The first has three parts: from whose perspective conventional truth is true and from whose perspective it is not true; the way mere conventional appears and does not appear to three types of persons; and how things become ultimate or conventional in relation to ordinary beings and noble ones. The first has two parts: the actual meaning and explaining the unique system of afflictions.

<1><29>As for the first: Since it obscures sentient beings from seeing the nature of how things actually exist, it is delusion. Ignorance is that which superimposes inherent existence upon phenomena that do not inherently exist by nature. That which has the nature of obscuring the vision of how things actually are is the conventional. This identifies the conventional in relation to which "truth" is posited in the term "conventional truth," rather than identifying what conventional means in general.

<1><29>This identification is also from the Lankavatara Sutra: "Things arise conventionally, but in ultimate truth they lack inherent existence. Whatever delusion there is regarding that which lacks inherent existence is accepted as conventional truth." This means that conventional truth is the mind that is deluded into seeing inherent existence where there is no ultimate inherent existence. Since the Sanskrit equivalent for 'conventional' (saṃvṛti) also means 'obscurer', it is an obscurer.

<1><29>When asked what it obscures, the term "perfect conventional" means it is accepted as conventional or concealing because it obscures the perfect meaning. This is not teaching it as the correct conventional among the two - correct and incorrect. The conventional taught in the first line and the conventional taught in the latter two lines should not be taken as one, because the first is the conventional in which things themselves are accepted as arising and so forth, while the latter is the conventional of grasping at true existence in whose perspective things are true.

<1><29>Through the power of grasping at conventional truth, things like blue - which lack inherent existence yet appear as if they had it - are fabricated appearances that appear as true to sentient beings. The Sage taught this as "worldly conventional truth" because it is true from the perspective of the worldly inverted conventions explained earlier. The way this was taught is as found in the previously mentioned sutra.

<1><29>Those entities that appear as fabricated due to being fabricated by false conceptualization from the perspective of the three types of persons, being untrue from the conventional perspective, are called "mere conventional." Some dependently arising phenomena like reflections and echoes appear as false to those possessing ignorance. Some things like blue and other forms, mind, and feelings appear as true. However, the natural way of being of phenomena does not appear in any way to those possessing ignorance. Therefore, that nature and whatever is false even conventionally are not conventional truths.

<1><29>Regarding the meaning of what was stated: The term "cung zad cig" is better translated as "aga zhig" ("some") as found in Naktso's translation. Although reflections and such are false, their appearance is a false appearance. This falseness consists in the combination of appearing as a face while being empty of it. Therefore, their emptiness of true existence means being empty of being truly a face, not the meaning that reflections are empty of true existence in the sense of being established by their own characteristics. Therefore, although a reflection is established as empty of being a face, there is no contradiction whatsoever in it being true from the perspective of conventional consciousness that grasps it as established by its own characteristics, thus making it a conventional truth.

<1><29>Therefore, when it is taught that reflections are not conventional truths, this means that from the perspective of worldly conventions of those familiar with symbols, something like a reflection of a face is false in being a face, and thus is not a conventional truth in that respect. However, this does not mean it cannot be posited as a conventional truth as explained in the statement "what is seen falsely is taught to be conventional truth." If it were not so, and if something's lack of conventional truth were incompatible with its being a conventional truth, this would contradict all presentations stating that there is no establishment through intrinsic characteristics even conventionally, and that the refutation of true existence and establishment of the absence of true existence are all done conventionally. Therefore, the claim that reflections and similar phenomena, being objects known to be mistaken even by ordinary worldly consciousness itself, are not conventional truths but mere conventions, shows a failure to understand the definitive enumeration of the two truths, the distinction between truth and falsity from a worldly perspective, and truth and falsity as posited by Madhyamikas.

<1><29>Regarding the statement that "nature does not appear at all to those endowed with ignorance," since it is accepted that noble ones who have not abandoned ignorance directly realize suchness, this refers to consciousness tainted by ignorance. Although the post-meditation wisdom of noble learners and ordinary beings' views of suchness, being tainted by ignorance and its latent tendencies, do not appear directly, ultimate truth must be accepted as appearing in general. Thus, when it is stated that conventional truth is established through afflicted ignorance included in the links of existence, the ignorance that grasps phenomena as true - known as the grasping at the self of persons and phenomena - is accepted as the ignorance of the twelve links, and therefore is not accepted as cognitive obscuration.

<1><29>The statement that conventional truth is posited due to the power of ignorance grasping at true existence shows the way in which conventional truth is posited from the perspective of someone who posits it. It does not mean that pots, woolen cloth and so forth, which are conventional truths, are posited by that grasping at true existence. This is because what is posited by that grasping at true existence is held to be impossible even conventionally. Therefore, since the conventional in the phrase "conventional truth" (referring to that in relation to which truth is posited) and the conventional in positing pots and so forth as existing conventionally are similar in name, it appears that many have confused them as being the same thing, so they should be carefully distinguished.

<1><29>Question: Are all these things like pots and so forth true from the conventional perspective of all individuals who have not attained enlightenment, or are there some individuals from whose conventional perspective they are not true? Answer: Regarding forms, sounds and so forth that are posited as conventional truths: for Hearers, Solitary Realizers, and Bodhisattvas who have abandoned afflictive ignorance and who see conditioned phenomena as being like reflections and so forth, these are artificial in nature and not true, because they have no conception of them as being true. When explaining the meaning of this statement, there are three types of individuals for whom these are not true: Hearers, Solitary Realizers, and Bodhisattvas.

<1><29>Moreover, regarding the special mention that this does not apply to just any śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, or bodhisattvas: one special quality is the direct realization that all conditioned phenomena, while empty of inherent nature like reflections, appear as such. Since this much is also present in bodhisattvas below the seventh ground and noble śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas who are still in training, in order to exclude these, it speaks of "the third person having abandoned ignorance," referring to bodhisattvas on the pure grounds and śrāvaka and pratyekabuddha arhats. It is from the perspective of these three that phenomena are not true.

<1><29>As for "whatever is untrue is also that," this refers to outer and inner phenomena. The reason for their being untrue is the conception of truth, because there is no attachment to truth, since the ignorance that grasps at true existence has been exhausted. Therefore, this establishes that outer and inner phenomena are not established as true from the conventional perspective of those three persons.

<1><29>Thus, when the Commentary establishes that "they are not truths" from their perspective, without ever establishing that they are not conventional truths - to maintain that it established they are not conventional truths is, due to an extremely coarse mental engagement, a bad system of explanation that contaminates the master's intended meaning with the stains of one's own mind.

<1><29>Such demonstration is not for those three individuals, but rather is a demonstration to other persons like ourselves that [phenomena] are not true from the perspective of those three. Since those below those three individuals possess innate grasping at truth, it is impossible to demonstrate that nothing is truly established from the perspective of all their conventions.

<1><29>If, contrary to what was explained above, one were to prove that these are not conventional truths from their perspective, it would become a completely irrelevant proof, because in order to establish something as a conventional truth from the perspective of that awareness, that basis must be established as false. Therefore, presenting the absence of clinging to truth as a reason in that context is an object of ridicule.

<1><29>The reason why, for a basis to be established as a conventional truth from the perspective of that awareness, that basis must be established as false is this: When positing the "truth" component in the term "conventional truth" as applied to pots and so forth, between awareness and object, truth is not posited in relation to the object but must be posited as true in relation to the conventional truth-grasping awareness itself. When one sees this, one must see that without applying this qualification, it cannot be established as true and is false - this is the key point.

<1><29>Second, it appears important to understand that there exists a unique identification of afflictions in this system that does not accord with what is explained in the higher and lower Abhidharma. Therefore, I will explain it: Regarding grasping at the true existence of things, there are two types - grasping at the true existence of persons and grasping at the true existence of phenomena. As previously explained, these are also asserted to be the two types of self-grasping.

<1><29>In both the Madhyamakavatara Commentary and the Four Hundred Commentary, grasping at truth is explained as afflictive ignorance. This ignorance is explained as being abandoned by Hearer and Solitary Realizer Arhats, and in the Four Hundred Commentary it is explained as being abandoned by bodhisattvas who have attained acceptance of the non-arising of phenomena. Therefore, afflictive ignorance is the opposite of the knowledge of the suchness of selflessness. Furthermore, this is not taken to be merely the absence of that knowledge or merely something other than that, but rather it is the opposite and discordant class - the superimposition that persons and phenomena are inherently established.

<1><29>Thus, positing the reification of a self of phenomena as afflicted ignorance, and positing the apprehension of 'I' and 'mine' as established by their own characteristics as the view of the transitory collection - these positions are not in agreement with the Abhidharmikas.

<1><29>According to the Abhidharma system, as explained in the ninth chapter of the Treasury Commentary, the view of the transitory collection that grasps at "I" is viewing the person as a self-sufficient substance, and the view of the transitory collection that grasps at "mine" is posited as viewing possessions as objects controlled by that substantially existent person. This is very different.

<1><29>Although the conception of persons as self-sufficient substantial entities exists even in those whose minds are not influenced by philosophical tenets, the conception of persons as existing differently from and with characteristics dissimilar to the aggregates does not exist in those whose minds are not influenced by philosophical tenets. Therefore, there are two types of views that grasp at extremes.

<1><29>If one asks how to establish that those who accept persons and phenomena to be established by their own characteristics have both afflicted ignorance and the two types of self-grasping: Since persons and phenomena being inherently established is negated by the reasonings that refute it, at that time such grasping is established as a grasping at true existence that is mistaken with respect to its conceived object. When that is established, grasping at both persons and phenomena as truly established is established as the two types of self-grasping. When these are established, since that grasping at true existence is established as the incompatible opposing factor to the cognition of suchness, it is established as ignorance. Moreover, since one can establish that as long as it is not exhausted, the view of the transitory collection is also not exhausted, it is established as afflicted ignorance. Therefore, it is very important to know how to posit the unique presentation of the afflictions.

<1><29>The way in which other afflictions such as desire also operate from the delusion of grasping at true existence is explained in the Four Hundred: "Just as the body faculty exists in the body, so delusion exists in all [afflictions]." The commentary states: "Delusion, being the ignorance that grasps at these things as true, thoroughly operates by greatly superimposing a truly existent nature onto things."

<1><29>Since attachment and so forth operate by superimposing distinctions of beauty, ugliness, and so forth exclusively upon the nature of things that are conceptually imputed by delusion, they operate inseparably from delusion and also depend on delusion, because delusion is primary. When explained as stated, up to where it says "operate" shows that delusion refers to grasping at true existence.

<1><29>The fact that attachment and other afflictions operate inseparably from ignorance means they function in conjunction with ignorance and do not operate independently of it. The reason for this is stated in the passage from "attachment and so forth" up to "because they operate." In this context, the superimposition of distinctions of attractiveness and unattractiveness upon objects is the improper mental engagement that causes attachment and aversion to arise, thus this does not indicate their mode of apprehension. Therefore, the statement that they operate "only upon what is imagined by ignorance" means that attachment and aversion function in dependence upon the superimposition of inherently existent attractiveness and unattractiveness.

<1><29>It is not taught that only what is truly established as imputed by ignorance serves as the object among the two - object and aspect - of attachment and so forth. This is because the object of both the object and aspect of the two innate self-graspings is an established basis, and because attachment and so forth are concomitant with ignorance, their objects are similar.

<1><29>The aspects of desire towards objects and aspects of aversion turning away that are induced by those two improper mental engagements become attachment and aversion. Therefore, merely having aspects of desire and non-desire that are induced by grasping at persons as self-sufficient substantial entities is not what is posited as attachment and anger. Thus, the way of positing these two - attachment and anger - is different.

<1><29>"They will also depend on delusion" means that attachment and so forth are drawn forth due to being preceded by the delusion that grasps at things as being established by their own characteristics.

<1><29>Regarding the example called "body faculty in relation to the body": Just as the other four faculties have no support separate from the body faculty, likewise all other afflictions operate in dependence on ignorance and operate without being separate from it. Therefore, since destroying ignorance itself destroys all afflictions, it is taught that one should respect precisely this discourse on emptiness of inherent existence through dependent origination, which is its antidote.

<1><29>This grasping at true existence of phenomena is taught in the Seventy Stanzas on Emptiness to be the fundamental ignorance that is the root of samsara. And in the Sixty Reasonings it states: "If one finds any basis whatsoever, one will be seized by the deceptive, poisonous snake of afflictions. Those whose minds have no basis will not be seized." Thus it teaches that if one finds any basis whatsoever as a focus for grasping at true existence, one will be seized by the snake of afflictions. And immediately following that, it states: "For those whose minds have a basis, how could the great poison of afflictions not arise?" Therefore, this is the supreme intent of the Noble One.

<1><29>Connecting the last two lines: It is taught to show that for those who, while perceiving the intrinsic nature of form and so forth, wish to abandon the afflictions, it is impossible to abandon the afflictions. And in the later commentary it states: When there is perception of entities, the vast afflictions such as attachment will definitely arise and cannot be reversed. How so? First, if that entity is agreeable to the mind, then attachment to it becomes difficult to reverse. If it is disagreeable, then anger and resentment toward it become difficult to reverse. The commentary states that even when an object is neither agreeable nor disagreeable, ignorance arises. When the apprehension of that object as established by its own characteristics operates in one's mindstream, either attachment or anger will arise, and even if these two do not arise, similar types of delusion will continue to operate.

<1><29>From the Bodhicaryāvatāra: "A mind that has an object will remain fixed on something. A mind devoid of emptiness, once ceased, will arise again - like the meditative absorption of non-perception." Thus it is stated. Regarding this point, there is no difference between these two masters and Buddhapālita in their interpretation of the Noble One's intention.

<1><29>By this key point, the explanation that one attains nirvana through merely the path of the sixteen aspects such as impermanence is provisional, and the identifications of afflictions made in terms of that path also remain incomplete. Based on those, one can also understand pride and so forth. Regarding the unique ignorance, view of the transitory collection, and extreme views as well, one should understand both their conceptually acquired and innate forms. However, fearing excessive words, I have not written about them.

<1><29>Similarly, having divided the conceptual thoughts that grasp phenomena as truly established into nine degrees of great and medium to be abandoned on the path of meditation and matching them with the nine antidotes of the path of meditation, and likewise, having divided the conceptual thoughts that grasp subject and object as substantially different entities into nine degrees of great and medium to be abandoned on the path of meditation and matching them with the nine levels of the path of meditation as what is to be abandoned and their antidotes - this should be understood as provisional meaning taught for the sake of certain disciples who, for the time being, cannot fully realize both subtle and coarse selflessness of phenomena.

<1><29>Second: These entities, while lacking intrinsic nature, appear to possess it to childish beings and thereby deceive them. However, for the three types of persons mentioned earlier who are different from these [childish ones], since they are dependently arising fabricated entities, they exist merely conventionally and not ultimately.

<1><29>Furthermore, because they operate with mere non-afflicted ignorance characterized as cognitive obscurations, noble ones abiding in post-meditation whose sphere of experience includes appearances tainted by ignorance and its habitual tendencies perceive these entities. However, they do not appear to noble ones abiding in meditative equipoise whose sphere of experience is free from appearances. When asked what this system considers cognitive obscurations to be, the Madhyamakāvatāra Commentary states: "The habitual tendencies of ignorance obstruct complete understanding of knowable objects, while habitual tendencies of attachment and so forth cause such physical and verbal engagement. These habitual tendencies of ignorance and attachment cease only in the omniscient Buddha, not in others." Regarding physical and verbal engagement, this refers to arhats' behaviors like jumping like monkeys or using crude speech - examples of negative physical and verbal predispositions that persist even when prohibited by the Buddha.

<1><29>Through the word "also," it is taught that the habitual tendencies of attachment and so forth are obstacles to cutting through objects of knowledge. Therefore, the habitual tendencies of afflictions are knowledge obscurations, and all aspects of deluded dualistic appearances that are their results are also included therein.

<1><29>Of the two - the latent tendencies established as seeds of afflictions and the latent tendencies that are not seeds of afflictions - the latter is posited as the cognitive obscuration. Although true-grasping does not arise due to the exhaustion of all seeds of afflictions, a mind that is mistaken with respect to appearing objects arises due to being contaminated by latent tendencies.

<1><29>Since noble beings who have not become buddhas have not abandoned the ignorance that constitutes cognitive obscuration, they experience alternating periods of conceptual thought with appearances in post-meditation and periods without appearances in meditative equipoise. However, since buddhas have fully and directly realized all aspects of both ultimate and conventional phenomena, all movements of conceptual thought of mind and mental factors have permanently ceased. Therefore, they do not experience alternating periods with and without conceptual thought and appearances in meditative equipoise and post-meditation.

<1><29>The term "permanently" indicates that for other noble ones, the cessation in meditative equipoise is occasional. Therefore, there is alternation between meditative equipoise and post-meditation. Thus, the statement "because they operate with the ignorance of cognitive obscurations" is not a reason for the existence of appearances, but rather evidence for the alternation between presence and absence of appearances during meditative equipoise and post-meditation.

<1><29>The movement of mind and mental factors is accepted to be conceptual thought. As explained in the Clear Words: "Conceptual thought is the movement of mind. Because it is free from that, suchness itself is without conceptual thought. As stated in a sūtra: 'What is ultimate truth? That which has no movement of mind whatsoever, what need is there even to mention words?'"

<1><29>Third: That which is the ultimate truth for ordinary beings is merely conventional truth for noble ones who have a domain with appearances. Whatever is the empty nature of that is their ultimate truth. The meaning of the first part of this statement is: Those very vases and so forth that ordinary beings grasp as ultimately established are merely conventional truth for the three noble ones previously explained who have appearances in post-meditation after arising from meditative equipoise. This indicates that it eliminates mere truth from their perspective but does not eliminate it being conventional truth. It does not teach that the object conceived by ordinary beings grasping vases etc. as ultimately established becomes conventional for noble ones, because that is impossible.

<1><29>The meaning of the latter text is: Since it teaches that the nature of conventional dependent origination is the ultimate reality for noble ones, those who speak contrary to the text by saying "a single basis such as a vase is conventional in relation to ordinary beings and ultimate in relation to noble ones" - this is talk that demonstrates a failure to understand that whatever appears as conventional truth from the perspective of a mind must be negated as truth from that same perspective.
<1><29>The ultimate of the Buddhas is nature itself, and since that is nondeceptive, it is the ultimate truth, and that is to be individually realized by themselves. Thus it is taught.

<1><29>The word "itself" in "is nature itself" is a term of exclusion, and what it excludes is this: unlike the ultimate truth of other noble ones which alternates between being of the nature of non-appearance during meditative equipoise and being of the nature of appearance during post-meditation, it is the ultimate reality that remains equipoised on the nature at all times.

<1><29>Regarding the meaning of "that also" and so forth: wishing to show that ultimate truth is not truly established, it is explained that truth means that which abides without deception from the perspective of one who sees suchness.

<1><30>The second has two parts: explaining the meaning of the root text and dispelling objections to it. Regarding the first: In order to teach ultimate truth, since ultimate truth cannot be expressed through words and is not an object of cognition following words, it cannot be directly taught. Therefore, to illuminate its nature for those wishing to hear, an example from ordinary beings' experience is explained. As stated in Nag-tsho's translation, "it cannot be directly demonstrated." The Clear Words commentary explains this through the analogy of someone with eye disease seeing floating hairs - even when shown by someone with clear vision that no hairs exist, they cannot perceive their absence as the person with clear vision does. This does not mean they cannot understand the absence of hairs at all. Similarly, while one may not realize ultimate truth exactly as those free from ignorance's distortions do, this does not mean one cannot realize it at all. Therefore, ultimate truth can be taught through definitive scriptures about profound meaning and understood through proper cognition following such teachings.

<1><30>Due to the power of eyes afflicted by an eye disease, when someone with impaired vision sees hairs and such things as flies within their eating and drinking vessel made of rhinoceros horn or similar materials that they hold in their hand, although these perceived hairs, flies and such are false in nature, upon examination, understanding that they wish to remove them, they undertake the effort of repeatedly shaking and turning that vessel.

<1><30>When someone with clear eyes free from floaters approaches them and focuses their eyes on the exact location where those hair-strands and such were seen, they neither perceive those hair-like appearances nor conceptualize any qualifying properties dependent on those hair-strands. Furthermore, when someone with floaters expresses their thought to someone without floaters saying "I see hair-strands," at that time, wishing to dispel the misconceptions of the person with floaters, speaking for their benefit, although they utter words emphasizing negation saying "There are no hair-strands here," the speaker is not denying the hair-strands.

<1><30>The true nature of floating hairs seen by one with diseased vision is what is seen by one without diseased vision, not what is seen by one with diseased vision. Understand the meaning in this context just as in these two examples. The way to understand is this: Those who do not see reality because their minds are corrupted by being harmed by the diseased vision of ignorance - their perception of the intrinsic nature of the aggregates, elements, sense bases and so forth is the conventional nature of those aggregates and so forth, like floating hairs perceived by one with diseased vision.

<1><30>Those very objects that are perceived due to not seeing the suchness of the aggregates and so forth are seen by the buddhas—who are free from the cognitive obscurations that are the habitual tendencies of ignorance—in the manner that those without cataracts do not see floating hairs. That nature of the aggregates and so forth which they perceive as their object is the ultimate truth of those buddhas.

<1><30>Second: If, just as eyes free from visual distortion do not see even the mere appearance of hair strands, the buddhas do not see conventional phenomena such as the aggregates that appear to minds corrupted by ignorance, then these would become non-existent, because if they existed, the buddhas would necessarily see them.

<1><30>If conventional phenomena such as the aggregates and so forth did not exist, then there would be no attainment of buddhahood, since the person who first generates bodhicitta is one affected by ignorance - thus one might object. When explaining how this fault does not exist: The way in which a buddha's primordial wisdom knows objects of knowledge is twofold: the way of knowing all objects of knowledge of ultimate truth and the way of knowing all objects of knowledge of conventional truth. Of these, the first is knowing the suchness of those conventional appearances such as the aggregates and so forth in the manner of not seeing them.

<1><30>As for the second: Since inferential realization (where things are understood without appearing) cannot be posited for a buddha, things must be known through direct appearance. Therefore, from the perspective of the wisdom that knows the diversity of phenomena, they are known in the manner of subject and object appearing as dual.

<1><30>Although the buddhas' knowledge of diversity is not an appearance of aggregates and so forth due to being contaminated by the habitual tendencies of ignorance, the appearances to other persons' consciousness that is contaminated by ignorance must appear to buddhas, because without such appearances it would be impossible, and if such conventional truths exist, they must be perceived by the knowledge of diversity.

<1><30>Although in visual consciousness free from eye disease there is no appearance of the floating hairs that appear to those with eye disease, it is not necessary that such appearances do not exist, and thus this is unlike the case of the Buddha.

<1><30>Until the habitual tendencies of dualistic appearance-based delusion are exhausted, since direct perception of both the ultimate nature and conventional phenomena cannot arise as one essence, they must be perceived alternately during meditation and post-meditation. Therefore, these two cannot be perceived within a single moment of wisdom. When the habitual tendencies of delusion are completely eliminated, since the two wisdoms arise uninterruptedly as one essence in each single moment of wisdom, there is no need to alternate between directly perceiving or not perceiving the two objects of knowledge simultaneously. Thus, there is no contradiction in the statement that "Even with a single moment of wisdom, it pervades the entire mandala of objects of knowledge."

<1><30>Although the two wisdoms are of one essence, there is not even the slightest contradiction in there being two different ways of knowing in relation to two objects. This is a unique quality of the Buddha Bhagavan alone. Taking only the way of knowing suchness to be the Buddha's way of knowing, some say that the knowledge of phenomena is not present in the Buddha's mindstream but is included in disciples' mindstreams, thus deprecating the Buddha's knowledge of phenomena. Some appear to deprecate both wisdoms by saying that even the knowledge of suchness is not present in the Buddha's mindstream. Some of the remainder will be explained in the section on the fruition.

<1><30>If all dualistic appearances have ceased, isn't such a nature unseen? Therefore, how do those buddhas see ultimate truth? In the perspective of seeing suchness, since dualistic appearances have ceased, they do not see in a dualistic manner. However, it is said that they see in the manner of not seeing. This answers the objection for three reasons: because the wisdom knowing suchness directly sees the suchness of the aggregates and so forth; because the non-establishment of the aggregates and so forth in that perspective of seeing is their suchness; and because it is necessary to see their suchness in the manner of not seeing the aggregates and so forth. As the Auto-Commentary states: "Without touching produced things, by directly realizing nature alone, because they have realized suchness, they are called buddhas." This statement that a buddha's wisdom knowing ultimate truth realizes dharmatā alone without touching dharmin is equivalent to saying they see the suchness of those aggregates in the manner of not seeing them.

<1><30>As for the meaning of the statement "Not seeing is supreme seeing," it does not accept mere non-seeing of anything as seeing. Rather, as explained previously, not seeing elaborations is established as seeing freedom from elaborations. Therefore, seeing and not seeing are not applied to the same basis. As stated in the Condensed Perfection of Wisdom: "Not seeing forms and not seeing feelings, not seeing discriminations and not seeing volitions, where there is no seeing of consciousness, mind, and mentality - this is seeing phenomena, as taught by the Tathāgata. When beings speak the words 'seeing space,' how is space seen? Examine this! The Tathāgata taught that seeing phenomena is likewise. Seeing cannot be explained by any other example." Here, what is not seen refers to the five aggregates, and what is seen is called "phenomena," which means suchness, as stated in "Whoever sees dependent origination sees phenomena."

<1><30>Furthermore, for example, space is merely the cutting off of obstructive touch. Seeing or realizing it is like making [the determination of] not seeing when that which is to be negated - obstruction - would be perceivable if it existed. In that case too, there is the seen space and the unseen obstruction. Similarly to that example, the final line refutes [the notion that] seeing suchness is like seeing blue without seeing.

<1><30>As evidence that [the Buddha] sees in the manner of not seeing, from the Entry into the Two Truths: "Divine child, if ultimately the ultimate truth were to become the nature of objects of body, speech and mind, then it would not count as what is called ultimate truth - it would become conventional truth."

<1><30>However, divine child, ultimately, ultimate truth transcends all conventions. It is without distinction, unborn, unceasing, and free from what is to be spoken and speaking, and from what is to be known and knowing. The meaning of the earlier cited sutra is this: When ultimate truth appears to one who sees the ultimate, it is not seen by way of not seeing conventional phenomena like the aggregates. Rather, if it were to become an object like the aggregates that are objects of bodily and verbal activity and objects of mind, then from the perspective of direct perception of suchness, it would not be free from elaborations and thus would not be ultimate truth but would become conventional elaboration. When understood thus, this serves as evidence for how it is seen in the manner of not seeing.

<1><30>The meaning of the second sutra is that from the perspective of those who directly see the ultimate, ultimate truth without distinction means there are not many different features. The other three are easy to understand.
<1><30>In that perspective, being free from the activities of speech is easy.

<1><30>Although the wisdom that directly perceives suchness can be posited as the ultimate understanding and ultimate truth can be posited as its object of knowledge, it is not contradictory that from the perspective of that wisdom, there is freedom from the duality of action and agent. This is because the duality of action and agent is posited only from the perspective of conventional mind. For example, just as although rational inferential cognition can be posited as the subject and ultimate truth as its object, the duality of object and subject is not posited from the perspective of rational cognition. Then divine child, ultimate truth transcends being an object even of omniscient wisdom that is endowed with the supreme of all aspects. It is not as it is expressed when saying "This is ultimate truth."

<1><30>All phenomena are false and deceptive phenomena. The meaning of this citation is: Up to "yin te" demonstrates how ultimate truth transcends being an object of omniscient wisdom. The manner in which it transcends being such an object is shown from "just as" through "ma yin no": When one states "This is ultimate truth," to the conceptual thought following that verbal expression, subject and object appear as two separate things. Just as it appears that way, it transcends being an object of the omniscient wisdom that knows suchness. Since all dually-appearing phenomena are false and deceptive phenomena, they do not exist from the perspective that sees only non-deceptive suchness. These sources demonstrate that conventional phenomena like aggregates do not appear from the perspective of directly seeing suchness. Therefore, in the perspective of directly seeing suchness, all elaborations of dualistic phenomena such as existence and non-existence are impossible, because their own nature is not observed there. Thus, regarding contemplation of suchness, only noble ones are direct valid cognizers, while non-noble ones are not direct valid cognizers. Therefore, worldly perception cannot invalidate the refutation of production from other in the perspective of noble ones' ultimate perception.

<1><31>Fourth: Regarding those who wish to raise worldly objections to the ultimate refutation of other-arising - if one accepts worldly perception as valid cognition when analyzing reality, then since ordinary worldly people would directly perceive reality, and since this would have been the case since beginningless time, one would have to accept they had abandoned ignorance. Therefore, what need would there be for other noble ones to directly realize reality? And what purpose would seeking the noble path serve? It is not reasonable for ordinary foolish worldly people to be valid cognizers of reality. Therefore, since worldly perception is not valid cognition in any respect when analyzing reality, there can be no worldly refutation in the context of reality. Some criticize this system as incorrect because the statement "worldly perception is not valid in all ways" appears to reject all valid cognition, while others praise it for the same reason. Both speak without understanding this master's intent, merely revealing their own views, as they misinterpret the statement about worldly perception's invalidity regarding reality as a general rejection of valid cognition.

<1><32>Regarding valid cognition and objects of cognition, as explained in Prasannapadā (Clear Words), having refuted their establishment through inherent nature, they must be understood as being posited through mutual dependence. This will be explained below.

<1><32>Fifth: If one asks "How does the world invalidate?", when someone refutes through worldly consensus what is renowned and established from the world itself, that person will be invalidated by the world. For example, when someone says "My substance was stolen" and another person asks "What is that substance?", they reply "It's a pot." Then that other person refutes saying "A pot is not a substance because it is a measurable object, like a pot in a dream." The world invalidates regarding such objects. However, when establishing suchness while relying on the noble ones' vision of ultimate truth and taking as authoritative those beings who are learned in ultimate truth, there is no invalidation by the world.

<1><32>When it states "the learned should analyze other aspects in this way," it demonstrates how conventional understanding refutes those who currently consider it great Madhyamaka reasoning when they say "I am not the owner of the pot and Devadatta is not the thief," and when someone says "It grew in my field" and is asked "What grew?" and answers "A sprout," they claim "The sprout has no arising because it is an object of valid cognition," and speak of it being "like a dream person and dream sprout."

<1><33>Second: Having accepted arising from other in accordance with worldly convention, and having addressed worldly objections, now - since there is no arising from other even in worldly perception - in order to show that there are no worldly objections even when one wishes to refute arising from other while remaining within the worldly view, the following is explained.

<1><33>For what reason do worldly people, when indicating someone possessing male organs, say "I have produced this son"? Although they make such statements, it is not the case that this father extracts someone possessing male organs from his own body and places him into the mother of that son. What then? He merely deposits the impure substance that becomes the seed of that son's body into that mother's womb.

<1><33>Because this father, having placed the cause of that son's body, points out his own son, therefore it is clearly established in the world that the seed and son are not held to be different entities established by their own characteristics. Therefore, even in the world there exists no conception of arising from other regarding the seed's impurity and the son, or the barley seed and sprout, and so forth.

<1><33>If one conceives of things as inherently established as different, then just as with another person, one would not point to the son and say "I produced this." Similarly, when merely planting a tree seed and a tree grows from it, one thinks "I planted this tree." Therefore, as before, one should apply [the reasoning that] in the worldly perspective there is no arising from other. Although the two planted seeds are not the tree and son themselves, when a tree and son arise depending on planting those two, one can validly point to them and say "I produced this." This is like how although a sick or healed hand is not that person, one can validly designate that person as sick or healed due to their hand being sick or healed.

<1><33>Thus, although there is no arising from other in worldly conventions, the existence of arising from other cannot be refuted by worldly perception, because the refutation of cause and effect being inherently different entities definitely depends on reasoning that analyzes suchness. Therefore, the meaning of arising from other accepted by other philosophical proponents is arising from other that is established through intrinsic characteristics, not merely being established as different entities. And it is also not the case that merely that much is not established from the worldly perspective.

<1><33>Regarding the meaning of "There is no arising from other even in the world": This is not merely saying that ordinary worldly beings do not grasp the substantial cause and effect (such as seeds and sprouts) as being inherently established as different. It should also be understood as demonstrating that there is no other-arising even conventionally. As clearly stated in the commentary on refuting arising from both: "Just as it was shown above that arising from self and other is not reasonable either conventionally or ultimately, similarly, for those who assert both, it is impossible according to the reasoning previously explained."

<1><33>In Clear Words too: "If things do not arise from self, other, both, or without cause, how is it that the Blessed One taught 'Through the condition of ignorance, formations arise'?" Let me explain this: "This is conventional, not suchness." Thus it is taught that ignorance giving rise to formations and so forth is conventional, not ultimate.

<1><33>In response to the question "Is the conventional presentation to be expressed?", it states: "We accept the establishment of conventional truth merely through these present conditions (rkyen 'di pa tsam), but not through accepting the four alternatives." Thus, it clearly states that even while accepting conventional dependent arising - where this arises in dependence on these conditions - one does not accept arising in terms of the four alternatives. Therefore, the statement that "this system does not refute other-arising conventionally" is an explanation by one who has not properly understood this system.

<1><34>Third, regarding the manner in which entities lack inherent existence as previously explained: In order to demonstrate the quality of not falling into the extremes of eternalism and nihilism through establishing dependent origination as free from eternalism and nihilism, it is explained thus: If a sprout were inherently established as different from its seed, since these two - seed and sprout - would not be suitable as cause and effect, without doubt, even while the sprout exists, the seed would be annihilated. In this case, since the seed and sprout would become unrelated, even though the sprout exists, it would not benefit the prevention of the seed's lineage from being cut off. For example, just as the existence of a non-cow does not benefit the prevention of a dead cow's lineage from being cut off, and just as the existence of ordinary beings does not benefit the prevention of noble ones' severance of their own cyclic existence.

<1><34>Thus, for the reason that there is no contradiction in the seed and sprout being cause and effect in the position that the sprout is not inherently established as different from the seed, when the sprout exists, the seed is destroyed - that is, its continuum is severed - and thereby the extreme of annihilation is avoided.

<1><34>Since it has been explained many times that the seed ceases at the time of the sprout, the Commentary explains the meaning of "the seed being destroyed" as the seed's continuum being interrupted, and since it is stated that the non-destruction of the seed is refuted, the phrase "interruption of the seed's continuum" is understood to mean the interruption of its lineage.

<1><34>Because the seed and sprout do not exist as one entity, and because that seed itself does not transfer into the sprout, the non-destruction of the seed at the time of the sprout is refuted. Therefore, one should not assert that the seed exists at the time of the sprout, thus refuting permanence. This is explained in the Lalitavistara: "When there is a seed, just as there is a sprout; what is the seed is not the sprout itself; it is neither other than that nor identical to that; thus this is the nature of things - neither permanent nor annihilated." The meaning is this: when there is a seed, the sprout that is caused by the seed arises accordingly. When it arises, since it cannot arise as something other than the seed, one might think the seed and sprout are one in essence. However, although the sprout does not arise as other than the seed, the seed itself does not transform into the sprout...

<1><34>Furthermore, this shows the qualification of the object of negation as 'free from inherent establishment,' which has the same meaning as 'non-existent in ultimate reality.' The meaning of that sūtra is also taught in the treatise Madhyamaka-śāstra: "Whatever arises in dependence upon something is neither that very thing itself nor something other than it. Therefore it is neither permanent nor annihilated."

<1><35>The fourth has two parts: refuting the assertion that things exist through their own characteristics, and dispelling objections to that refutation. The first has three parts: refutation through the consequence that noble ones' meditative equipoise would be a cause of destroying things, refutation through the consequence that conventional truth would withstand analysis by reasoning, and refutation through the consequence that ultimate production would not be negated. Regarding the first: As it is stated, "It must definitely be accepted that no phenomenon whatsoever is produced through its own nature." It is appropriate to say this point must definitely be accepted. One should not say the opposite - that it is not appropriate to posit an acceptance of this.

<1><35>That is not so. If the intrinsic characteristics of form, feeling, and so forth - namely their nature established through their own essence - were to arise in dependence on causes and conditions, then when yogis directly realize that phenomena are empty of intrinsic existence, they would realize emptiness by way of negating the intrinsic nature of things. For meditative equipoise must not perceive forms and so forth, and if these existed through their own characteristics, they would necessarily be perceived in meditative equipoise, yet they are not perceived. Therefore, at that time those things would become non-existent. If they do not exist, then those things that existed before meditative equipoise would later be destroyed or cease. Therefore, since meditative equipoise itself would necessarily be the cause of such destruction, just as hammers and so forth are causes for destroying pots and so forth, seeing emptiness would also become a cause for destroying and negating the intrinsic nature of things. However, this is not reasonable. Therefore, since things do not exist through their own characteristics, one should never accept intrinsic arising.

<1><35>Regarding this, those Madhyamikas who accept arising established through own characteristics assert that although things are established through own characteristics, they do not become truly established. For this reason, they say that if forms and so forth were established through own characteristics, they would not need to be observed by direct perception that sees suchness. However, as previously explained and as will be explained again through reasoning, they cannot avoid the fault that this much itself constitutes true establishment.

<1><35>Here in the Commentary, it quotes from the Ratnakūṭa where Kāśyapa is taught: "Furthermore, the middle way's correct individual analysis of phenomena is this: emptiness does not make phenomena empty - phenomena themselves are empty." Similarly, it quotes passages regarding signlessness, wishlessness, non-conditioning, non-arising, and non-occurrence. If phenomena possessed an intrinsic nature established by their own characteristics, since those phenomena would not be empty from their own side, the statement "phenomena themselves are empty" would be incorrect. Without refuting existence from their own side through essential nature, one would need to teach emptiness through being empty of something else, which would contradict the statement "emptiness does not make phenomena empty." Thus, when the middle way individually analyzes the nature of phenomena, it shows that phenomena are empty of intrinsic existence from their own side.

<1><35>This sūtra refutes both the Vijñaptivādin assertion that the dependent nature is not empty of establishment by its own characteristics and their claim that it is empty due to the non-existence of apprehender and apprehended as different substances. The Śatakaśāstra states: "Not seeing what is non-empty as empty; saying 'May nirvana become mine,' one cannot transcend sorrow through wrong views - thus taught the Tathāgatas." The Mūlamadhyamakakārikā also states: "The Victor has taught that emptiness definitely liberates from all views. Those who hold a view of emptiness are declared incurable." These also explain the meaning of the aforementioned sūtra.

<1><35>This is also the intended meaning of "phenomena are empty of their own essence." It is completely incorrect to say that "a pot being empty of true existence but not empty of pot is other-emptiness, therefore a pot being empty of pot is self-emptiness." If a pot were empty of pot, there would need to be no pot in the pot. If something does not exist in itself, it cannot exist in anything else, so the pot would become completely non-existent. At that time, since all other things would be similar to that, even the one making such statements would become non-existent, and any framework of "empty of this" and "not empty of that" would become impossible. Some assert such emptiness as authentic while others consider it nihilistic emptiness - both of these are outside what the Buddha and bodhisattvas have repeatedly established regarding dependent origination being free from the extremes of permanence and annihilation.

<1><35>In particular, those who say all conventional truths must be established as empty of themselves and assert this to be nihilistic emptiness are completely incorrect, because none among the four philosophical schools would generate such a view in their mindstream knowing it to be nihilistic. Therefore, although similar in that the basis of negation does not exist as the object of negation and in how the basis is empty of what is to be negated, the emptiness of phenomena being established by their own characteristics means being empty of their own entity. The reason other modes of emptiness are not empty of their own entity is this: while the first type of emptiness is established by valid cognition and its function remains unimpaired, superimposition grasping the basis as truly existent cannot arise. However, with the latter types, even though their meaning is established by valid cognition and their function remains unimpaired, philosophical tenets may still superimpose true existence.

<1><36>Second, here someone says: "Although it depends on refuting arising from self and other since there is no arising ultimately, the natures of form, feeling, and so forth that are observed by the two valid cognitions must definitely arise from other. If this is not accepted thus, why speak of two truths? There would be only one truth. Therefore," they say, "arising from other exists."
<1><36>Those who argue thus, since they appear to accept that there is no arising ultimately and assert arising from other conventionally, are some Svātantrika Madhyamikas.

<1><36>If intrinsically existent other-arising is not accepted conventionally, there would be only one truth - this means: if arising through own characteristics does not exist conventionally, there would be no genuine conventional truth. At that time, since conventional truth would be impossible, there would be only ultimate truth. In response to this, though this is true, ultimately there are not two truths. Monks, this ultimate truth is one - that is, nirvana which has the characteristic of being non-deceptive.

<1><36>Because it appears [in scripture] that "All compounded phenomena are false and have the nature of being deceptive." Thus it is said. The meaning of these [statements] is that since the meaning of truth that one accepts oneself is non-deceptive, it becomes only non-deceptive truth, therefore it is said "this is indeed true here."

<1><36>"In ultimate terms" means that from the perspective of seeing suchness, there are not two truths - conventional and ultimate - because it is taught that in that perspective there exists only the ultimate truth. The supreme truth is the ultimate truth. That conventional truth does not exist from the perspective of that wisdom is known from the teaching that it has the nature of being deceptive.

<1><36>In summary, if phenomena were established by way of their own characteristics, compounded phenomena would not be established as false and deceptive phenomena, therefore since there would be no conventional truth, there would be no two truths. Whereas on the position where there is no establishment by way of own characteristics, both conventional and ultimate truths exist - this is the meaning.

<1><36>If one thinks: "Since the previous scripture states that only nirvana is true while other conditioned phenomena are false, although conditioned phenomena are not established by their own characteristics, isn't nirvana, being the ultimate truth, established by its own characteristics?" - [the response is that] the truth of that [nirvana] is explained in the sutra itself as having the characteristic of being non-deceptive, but it is not a truth that is inherently established.
<1><36>Since it is stated that "all conditioned phenomena have the nature of being false and deceptive," one understands that the previously mentioned truth means non-deceptiveness.

<1><36>From the Commentary on Sixty Reasonings as well: Just as conditioned phenomena appear falsely and deceive the childish, nirvana appears in that same way through ultimate truth but does not deceive. Therefore, it is explained that nirvana is true while others are untrue. Thus, it must definitely be accepted that the division into true and untrue refers to the meaning of what deceives and what does not deceive.

<1><36>From the Commentary on the Sixty Reasonings, when it states that nirvana is true conventionally, the meaning is that nirvana, which exists as ultimate truth, is posited from the conventional perspective. It is not accepted that it is true conventionally. Thus, since conventional truth is the method for entering ultimate truth, just as worldly convention operates without analyzing arising from self and other, the Madhyamikas also accept it.

<1><36>Thus, when analyzing phenomena such as form and feelings in terms of whether they arise from self or from other, beyond their ultimate nature which is suchness—being unarisen and unceased—no other aspect characterized by arising and so forth is found. Therefore, conventional worldly truth should not be analyzed in terms of "from self" and "from other." Rather, one should accept merely this: "when this exists, that arises," through engaging in conventions that depend on others in the world. As Āryadeva stated: "Just as barbarians cannot be grasped through another language, likewise the world cannot be grasped without worldly conventions." And from the Mūlamadhyamakakārikā: "Without relying on conventions, ultimate truth cannot be understood. Without understanding ultimate truth, nirvana cannot be attained." And from the Vigrahavyāvartanī: "Without accepting conventions, we do not explain."

<1><36>Here, "analysis" and "non-analysis" refer to the analysis and non-analysis of suchness. Moreover, since it is important to understand from what point of analysis one begins analyzing suchness, I will explain briefly: According to the Prasangika system, when not being satisfied with mere conventional designations, as in the case of "the sprout arises," one investigates whether the referent of that designation arises from self or other - from that point onward it is established as analysis of suchness. Therefore, one should understand that this is entirely different from worldly conventional analyses such as "Where did it come from? Where did it go?" and "Where is it - outside or inside?"

<1><36>The Svātantrikas do not establish investigation into suchness at merely that point. Rather, as previously explained, they proceed to investigation of suchness only after investigating whether something exists by virtue of appearing to cognition, or whether it is established from the mode of existence of objects that is not posited by virtue of that appearing. Because they identify the object of negation differently, there are two distinct points where investigation of suchness begins. Without understanding this properly, some take the example of Devadatta who has not actually come to this place - first mistakenly believing he has come, then through investigation realizing he has not come - and wrongly conclude that all unpenetrated presentations are merely erroneous while all penetrated presentations are unerroneous. This is neither the system of Madhyamaka nor of valid cognition, since both systems acknowledge many things established by valid cognition within unpenetrated presentations. As this has been explained extensively elsewhere, I will not elaborate further.
<1><36>When examining conventional [phenomena] with reasoning that examines suchness, one should understand that all worldly conventions will be undermined.

<1><37>Third: If, when cutting through all clinging to things as truly existent, someone anxiously clings to conventional truth and says "We must posit some nature that is established by its own characteristics as substance that becomes the cause of both bondage and liberation of samsara and nirvana," then for one who speaks thus, only mere words remain.

<1><37>Why? Just as in the context of analyzing ultimate truth, the reasoning explained above shows that the arising of form and so forth from self and other is not reasonable, likewise even conventionally, that very reasoning shows arising is not reasonable. Therefore, by what valid cognition could intrinsically existent arising be established? It cannot be. Therefore, one must necessarily accept, even unwillingly, that arising through intrinsic characteristics does not exist in either of the two truths. This statement shows that the arising negated by reasoning analyzing ultimate truth, even conventionally, refers to arising of the nature of substance, as explained in the connecting passage and confirmed in the summary. Thus the qualification "through intrinsic characteristics" applies only to what is being negated, not to mere arising, because it has been repeatedly stated that ultimate analysis should not be applied to conventional objects.

<1><37>If reasoning analyzing suchness cannot negate arising that is established by its own characteristics conventionally, then it cannot negate ultimately established arising, because mere establishment by own characteristics constitutes true existence. Therefore, whether one applies the qualification "conventionally" or not makes no difference. Thus, countless qualifications of the object of negation such as "by own characteristics," "by intrinsic nature," and "by own essence" appear in the sūtras and in the texts of Nāgārjuna and Āryadeva and this master. When refuting such qualifications, some Mādhyamikas become the object of critique, as explained above. The Clear Words also states: "This must necessarily be accepted exactly thus. Otherwise, would the conventional not be established through reasoning? Therefore, this would become reality itself rather than conventional." When refuting those who are not satisfied with mere conventional designation and seek to establish conventional objects through analysis of the designated object, he argues this would make them ultimately existent and forms etc. would not be conventional. This applies to those who reject ultimate establishment of forms etc. while accepting them as conventional. Since this cannot apply to Realists, it clearly refers to Svātantrika Mādhyamikas.

<1><37>Here, some claim that when the Master states that the Noble One's words "Not from self, not from other" and so forth refute arising and so forth, this refers to the refutation of imagined arising where subject and object are substantially different, but does not refute the true existence of dependent nature. However, since this interpretation cannot be established without supporting reasoning, those who make such claims must only be disputed and examined. Although some earlier scholars say that Master Sthiramati and others held this opposing position, such statements do not appear in their texts.
<1><37>Since it is explained that Master Dharmapāla, in his commentary on the Four Hundred, interpreted the view of the Four Hundred as Cittamātra, it would be appropriate to apply it accordingly.

<1><37>Now, if one asks how those who interpret the meaning of the profound sutras as Cittamātra explain the meaning of the Noble One's texts: Although it does not appear clearly stated in the texts of great masters such as Ācārya Vasubandhu that "this is how they interpret the meaning of Nāgārjuna's texts," since it appears in works such as the Vyākhyāyukti that they explain the Prajñāpāramitā sutras as requiring interpretation based on the Saṃdhinirmocana Sutra, it is evident they would explain them similarly. For it is impossible that they would refute the Noble One's texts, and if they were to explain them literally, they would not explain the Prajñāpāramitā sutras non-literally, and if they explain the literal meaning as requiring interpretation, they must necessarily explain its meaning in terms of Cittamātra.

<1><37>However, since those statements that all phenomena are not ultimately established and not established by their own characteristics are established through reasoning in accordance with their literal meaning, and since there is no valid objection to their literal meaning, they cannot be interpreted as having provisional meaning. With this in mind, it is stated that "these are solely to be examined and investigated." Since showing countless refutations against non-literal interpretations and proofs supporting literal interpretations establishes that the meaning of the text cannot be interpreted differently, only a brief explanation is given here.

<1><38>Second: If arising that is established by own-characteristics does not exist in either of the two truths, then forms and so forth would become non-existent. In that case, the entities of forms and so forth would not be observed by eye consciousness and so forth in the world. Otherwise, even rabbit horns and so forth would appear to eye consciousness and so forth, since the reasoning would be completely equivalent. In response to this explanation: Empty things - that is, false things like reflections and so forth, including echoes and so forth - are not unknown but well-known in the world to arise in dependence on and reliance upon collections of causes and conditions such as mirrors, faces, caves, and the production of sound. Just as is known in the world, from empty (that is, false) things like reflections and so forth, eye consciousness and so forth bearing the aspect of those reflections arises.

<1><39>Just as from a false reflection arises a consciousness possessing a false aspect, similarly, although all phenomena are empty of establishment by way of their own characteristics, from causes that are empty of that, effects that are empty of that thoroughly arise. Here, since it is stated that from a reflection arises the visual consciousness that apprehends it, a reflection is a real phenomenon and, being different in essence from consciousness, is an external object. Moreover, since it is the objective condition of visual consciousness, it is accepted as a form sense-sphere. This should be understood similarly for the appearance of two moons, floating hairs, illusions, echoes, and so forth. Thus, reflections, double moons, floating hairs, and so forth that appear to mistaken sense consciousnesses are similar to phenomena established through their own characteristics appearing to the five sense consciousnesses that are free from temporary sensory impairment.

<1><39>Although appearances such as faces and so forth are impossible, their appearing as such is similar to how things appear to exist by their own characteristics despite such existence being impossible.

<1><39>Since reflections, echoes, and so forth are similar to forms, sounds, and so forth, although the five sense objects such as form are not posited as external due to being inherently established, the forms and so forth that appear as such are posited as external. Similarly, although reflections and so forth are not posited as external due to being faces and so forth, reflections and so forth are posited as external. Thus, these two are equivalent in terms of what is and is not posited as external.

<1><39>The mere falsity of a reflection being empty of a face is established through all conventional signs by worldly elders whose minds have not turned toward any scripture or reasoning teaching emptiness. Therefore, it is entirely unreasonable to assert that such understanding is a coarse rational cognition.

<1><39>If that is so, even though the conventionally known falsity of reflections is established, it does not establish the falsity posited by Mādhyamikas, so how can the former serve as an example of the latter? In this context, when presenting reflections and such as examples, they are presented as examples of what is already established by worldly convention, not as examples of what has already been established as false as posited by Mādhyamikas.

<1><39>Furthermore, regarding a reflection appearing as a face - at the level of its appearance, one cannot distinguish in any way saying "this much appears as a face" and "this much does not appear as a face." Although it is empty of existing as it appears from all aspects of what appears as the face, it is not contradictory for it to arise in dependence on its causes. Using this as an example, similarly, when blue appears to be established by its own characteristics, there are no distinguishable aspects of appearing and not appearing to be inherently established with respect to the blue. Although what appears this way is empty of existing as it appears from all aspects, it is not contradictory that it is produced by its causes and produces effects. That is, if one can understand how to posit that although a face's reflection does not exist as it appears from all aspects, it does not become non-existent as a reflection, then regarding blue as well, although there is no existence as it appears to be established by its own characteristics from all aspects, one can definitely posit blue's existence.

<1><39>Distinguishing through refined analysis the two aspects regarding form and so forth - "this is to be negated" and "this is not to be negated" - using the example of reflections is indispensable for finding the Madhyamaka view, so one should not be easily satisfied. Therefore, the commentary states: While establishing causation lacking intrinsic nature in reflections, what wise person who understands would determine things that exist merely as form, feeling and so forth, which are not separate from cause and effect, to have intrinsic nature simply by observing them? Therefore, though observed to exist, there is no inherent arising. This clearly distinguishes between mere existence and inherent existence, and between arising shown earlier and inherent arising shown here. Without these distinctions, as long as things exist they would exist by their own essence, and when lacking own essence would become utterly nonexistent, not transcending the two extremes of reification and negation. As stated in the Commentary on the Hundred: According to proponents of real entities, as long as something exists it has its own essence, and when separated from own essence becomes completely nonexistent like a donkey's horns, making all their assertions difficult to reconcile. Therefore, being free from all extremes of existence through lacking own essence, while able to establish causation lacking intrinsic nature within that very lack, appears as the special quality of Masters Buddhapālita and Candrakīrti's explanation of the Noble One's intent. Thus distinguishing the two types of existence and nonexistence is crucially important.

<1><39>Establishing through the example of reflection: From the Meeting of Father and Son: "Just as reflections appear in a completely pure mirror without inherent nature, likewise understand all phenomena including trees." Thus it is taught. You should understand how to correlate the meaning of other examples of falsity in the same way as before.

<1><39>The fifth has two parts: the quality of being able to easily abandon the views of eternalism and nihilism, and the quality of the relationship between actions and their results being highly tenable. Regarding the first: Because all phenomena are empty of inherent existence like reflections, for that very reason, since there is no inherent establishment in either or both of the two truths - ultimate and conventional - forms and so forth are neither inherently established permanent things nor are they annihilated. Annihilation here refers to what is explained in the context of there being no destruction of the seed when the sprout exists, and as stated in the Mūlamadhyamakakārikā: "What existed before is now nonexistent, therefore it would follow there is annihilation." If one accepts inherently established things and then asserts their impermanence through previous existence becoming nonexistent or through destruction, this becomes a nihilistic view. For it is taught that if one accepts inherent existence, whether asserting permanence or impermanence, one falls into the extreme views of eternalism and nihilism.

<1><39>Here, the commentary cites from the Mūlamadhyamakakārikā: "Just as the Teacher emanates an emanation and that one emanates another, likewise the agent, action, and what is done by that are like those." This teaches that things lacking intrinsic nature arise from things lacking intrinsic nature. This statement demonstrates that there is no nihilistic view since all actions and agents are established within what lacks intrinsic existence.

<1><39>Here, if establishment by way of intrinsic characteristics is not refuted conventionally, since one will not realize extremely subtle selflessness, it becomes difficult to prevent extremely subtle views of permanence and annihilation from arising in one's mindstream. Therefore, the complete abandonment of views of permanence and annihilation is the benefit of refuting that object of negation conventionally. If its conventional existence is refuted, not only will one not fall into views of permanence and annihilation with respect to the ultimate, but since one will not be tainted by the stains of views of permanence and annihilation with respect to the conventional, there exists the benefit of easily abandoning views of permanence and annihilation.

<1><39>The second has three parts: demonstrating that those who do not accept intrinsic existence need not accept foundation consciousness and so forth; demonstrating through examples how effects arise from ceased actions; and dispelling objections to these teachings. The first has three parts: explaining the transitional passage, explaining the meaning of the root text, and explaining the derivative points. Regarding the first: Not only does the absence of intrinsic existence in both truths cast views of permanence and annihilation far away, but it is also tenable that actions, even long after cessation, remain connected to their effects without having to conceptualize foundation consciousness, mental continuum, non-wastage, obtainment, and so forth. This demonstrates that the position rejecting intrinsic existence even conventionally not only has the advantage of casting eternalist and nihilist views far away but also has the advantage of establishing the connection between actions and effects without accepting foundation consciousness and so forth.

<1><39>Although there is not even a particle established through its own characteristics in the way of commenting on the Noble One's texts, based on this unique system of commentary that allows for positing all actions and activities, there are many unique pure philosophical tenets not shared with other commentators. What are these? To state just the main ones: (1) the foundation consciousness being a distinct entity from the six collections of consciousness; (2) the unique way of refuting self-awareness; (3) not accepting that the view of suchness can be generated in an opponent's continuum through autonomous syllogisms; (4) just as consciousness must be accepted, external objects must also be accepted; (5) Hearers and Solitary Realizers have the realization that phenomena lack inherent existence; (6) positing grasping at the self of phenomena as an affliction; (7) disintegratedness being a thing; and (8) because of this reason, the unique way of positing the three times, etc. The first of these is taught in this context. How the non-acceptance of self-awareness leads to the rejection of inherent existence will be explained.
