<1><39>The way of not accepting autonomous syllogism has been explained extensively elsewhere, and a brief explanation will also be given here.

<1><39>How this relates to accepting external reality will be explained later. How the fifth also relates to this is as follows: Just as Buddhapālita explained that the self that is negated when the Śrāvaka scriptures state "all phenomena are selfless" means establishment through intrinsic nature, this is accepted here as well. This is the meaning of complete characteristics of selflessness. Therefore, the complete characteristics of the selflessness of persons must be taken to mean the absence of persons being established through their own intrinsic nature. The key point is that to realize this correctly, one must also realize the correct selflessness of phenomena. This being so, one must accept that grasping at the self of phenomena is definitely an affliction. Thus, there are many differences, such as the two ways (coarse and subtle) of identifying afflictions, the two positions on whether liberation occurs through just the path of the sixteen aspects like impermanence, and the different points at which cognitive obscurations are eliminated.

<1><39>Well then, both Madhyamaka schools must accept that it is possible for someone who initially entered the Mahāyāna and well established the view of suchness to fall into the śrāvaka or pratyekabuddha paths. If so, one must accept that such a person directly realizes the selflessness of phenomena through meditation and cultivates what has already been seen. If so, one must accept that this path eliminates the conceptually acquired grasping at the self of phenomena from the path of seeing, and also eliminates the innate grasping at that self from the path of meditation. This being so, one might wonder whether even in the Madhyamaka system that accepts things to be established by their own characteristics, there are two types of grasping at the self of phenomena - afflictive and non-afflictive. Although this is not clearly explained, these Svātantrika Mādhyamikas must maintain that while śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas meditating on such a path may temporarily eliminate manifest grasping at the self of phenomena, without the support of accumulating limitless merit, they cannot eliminate the seeds of either type of grasping at the self of phenomena. Therefore, one must assert that while it's possible for śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas to temporarily eliminate manifest cognitive obscurations, it's impossible for them to eliminate their seeds.

<1><39>According to this master's view, since grasping at the self of phenomena is an affliction, abandoning its seeds does not require the support of accumulating infinite collections. However, for purifying the cognitive obscurations that are the habitual tendencies of delusory dualistic appearances, he maintains it cannot be purified without such support. I have explained this because understanding these previously explained points appears to make a very great difference.

<1><40>As for the second: Regarding the question "How is the connection between karma and its effects valid even without accepting foundation consciousness and so forth in the position that accepts that things are not inherently established?": All Buddhist schools, both higher and lower, accept that from virtuous and non-virtuous karma separated by a long time from its effects, results such as happiness and suffering arise. If that karma were to remain until just before producing its effect, it would become permanent. Since a permanent thing cannot perform a function, the connection of effects arising from karma would not be valid.

<1><40>If the action ceases in the second moment after it has been performed, then from that point until just before directly producing the result, that action does not exist. And since the ceased action is also not an entity, how can a result arise from the action? In response to this objection: When the action is about to cease in the second moment after being performed, some posit a foundation consciousness (kun gzhi rnam par shes pa) to establish the action's power. Others assert a non-associated compositional factor called "nonwastage" (chud mi za ba), which is different from both actions and is similar to a loan document.
<1><40>Some think that what is called "the attainment of the two karmas" is a nonassociated factor that has become a different entity from those two.

<1><40>Some posit a consciousness-continuum impregnated with karmic latencies. Therefore, they maintain there is no contradiction in karma producing its result long afterward even though the karma has ceased. Since karma deposits latencies in the ālaya-vijñāna, these latencies are karma's result, and through the continuation of similar types, it finally produces results - thus they maintain the results of the original karma arise through continuation. The other three should be understood similarly. Of these, the first is held by some Cittamātrins. The second is explained by Avalokitavrata to be the Vaibhāṣika view, specifically one different from the Kashmiri Vaibhāṣikas. The third is also a subdivision of the Vaibhāṣikas. Although the fourth is not explicitly identified, when correlated with the ninth chapter of the Abhidharmakośa commentary, it appears to be the view of both the Sautrāntikas and Kashmiri Vaibhāṣikas.

<1><40>Although the Kashmiris accept obtainment, they do not assert that obtainment is produced by two factors - the phenomenon to be obtained and [obtainment itself]. However, here it is asserted in that way - this is the meaning of the phrase "according to whom."

<1><40>According to the Prasangika Madhyamika, since karma does not arise by its own nature, and because it is not contradictory for results to arise even from karma that is intrinsically unceasing and has not intrinsically ceased, therefore even without accepting alayavijnana and so forth, because results can arise from karma, understand that even when two karmas performed in some sentient beings' continuum have ceased and a long time - many eons - has passed, genuine results arise from karma without error in relation to their causes. Thus, in this system, the connection between karma and results becomes thoroughly well-established. The meaning of these statements is that all four respondents to the previous debate accept that karma's arising and ceasing are established by their own characteristics, and they maintain that after karma is performed, its cessation is established by its own nature.

<1><40>Regarding this, it is incorrect for this master to respond by saying "although there is such cessation, there is no fault because we accept the foundation consciousness and so forth," because there is no inherently established arising and ceasing of karma.

<1><40>To demonstrate that this way of answering is Ārya Nāgārjuna's intended meaning, he quotes from the Mūlamadhyamakakārikā: "Because karma has no arising, as it lacks intrinsic nature, and because it is unarisen, therefore it does not perish." The meaning is: Because karma lacks intrinsic existence, it does not arise through its own nature. Therefore, since it is impossible for karma to cease intrinsically, it is not reasonable to think that after karma has been performed and ceased, it exists intrinsically and does not perish.
<1><40>Although this reasoning was taught for refuting non-wastage, there is no difference in refuting the other three, because the reasons are completely equivalent.

<1><40>Furthermore, from a sutra: "The human lifespan is one hundred years, and though it is said they live that long, there is no heap of years. That accomplishment too is similar to that. What is spoken of as 'inexhaustible' and what is spoken of as 'exhaustion of karma' - in terms of emptiness there is no exhaustion, while in terms of convention exhaustion is taught." This is cited as a source showing that there is no inherently established exhaustion or cessation, and that these two are posited through the force of convention.

<1><40>From Naktso's translation: "Just as years heaped into a pile do not exist, one should likewise view this collection as truly non-existent." Thus it appears. These are explained in terms of applying a qualification to what is to be negated, namely "not ceasing by way of intrinsic nature."

<1><40>The third has two parts: how the lack of inherent cessation serves as a reason for not accepting the alayavijñana, and how a basis for habitual tendencies is established even without accepting the alayavijñana.$$Regarding the first: If someone objects: Although there is no inherently established cessation, in our own system it is stated that "in some cases karma ceases" and that "having ceased and lacking inherent nature," showing it is merely taught in conventional terms. Thus, after karma is performed, one must accept that karma ceases. At that time, since cessation is not a real entity and you don't accept alayavijñana or similar bases for the karma-result relationship, when a long time has passed after karma has ceased, the arising of results would be untenable - this objection remains, so the previous answers are insufficient.$$There is no fault. Because of the very reason stated in "since it does not inherently cease," the later result arising from the disintegration of ceased karma is established. Therefore, no separate answer was given.

<1><40>Moreover, for all positions that assert things to be established by their own nature, destruction cannot be a thing, while for the Madhyamaka position that asserts things are not established by their own nature, destruction is established as a thing - this is the key point. According to the first system, when a thing like a sprout is destroyed, all the material parts of the sprout have ceased, and no other thing like a pot has been obtained. Therefore, they assert that destruction is absolutely not a thing, thinking that neither individual sense objects like blue, nor collections of parts constituting things like pots can serve as instances of that destruction. According to the latter system, for example, neither the five aggregates of Nyerbas individually or collectively, nor something different in nature from these two, can be posited as instances of Nyerbas, and Nyerbas cannot serve as an instance of these three. Yet just as there is no contradiction in Nyerbas being a thing when designated in dependence upon his aggregates, similarly, although destruction has no instances in either the destroyed thing or similar types of things, it is a thing because it arises in dependence upon the thing that was destroyed.

<1><40>In proving this, regarding the two approaches - scripture and reasoning - stated in <Clear Words>, the first comes from the <Ten Grounds Sutra>, which states: "Due to the condition of birth, there is aging and death." Death is the destruction of whatever sentient being has died, and it is taught to be produced by the condition of birth. Furthermore, that same text states: "Death abides as two functions - it destroys the conditioned factors and produces the cause of uninterrupted ignorance." Thus it teaches that death performs two functions: it is produced by causes and it produces ignorance. Therefore, destruction can have a productive cause and can produce effects. Although this refers to the destruction of a continuum, it applies equally to the destruction of the first moment at the time of the second moment, and it also demonstrates how the first moment causes destruction at the time of the second moment. Thus, whether between a sentient being's birth and death, or between a moment's non-persistence and having not persisted in the second moment, they are completely equivalent in terms of both their status as entities and their production by causes.

<1><40>In consideration of this, the Root Wisdom states: "Things and non-things are conditioned phenomena," and the Sixty Reasonings also states: "Peace from the exhaustion of causes is observed as what is called exhaustion." Thus, both things such as sprouts and their non-existence (which is their disintegration) are conditioned phenomena, and the exhaustion of causes like oil is taught to be the cause of the exhaustion of effects like butter lamps. This must definitely be accepted as the Noble One's position.

<1><40>Since the destruction of the first moment in the second moment must be understood through directly cutting off the object of negation, it is a negation but not a non-affirming negation; therefore, it is an affirming negation. This is because it does not merely cut off what is to be destroyed but implies a positive phenomenon that results from that cutting off. The remaining proofs should be understood in detail from the commentary on the Mulamadhyamakakarika. This represents one of the subtle yet greatly significant reasonings of this system.

<1><40>Second, even if one does not accept the ālayavijñāna (foundation consciousness), one must accept that habitual tendencies of virtuous and non-virtuous actions are deposited and that results arise from the maturation of those habitual tendencies. This is because the Madhyamakāvatārabhāṣya states: "The complete maturation of habitual tendencies of entities deposited in beginningless saṃsāra, manifest [clinging] to entities..." and because many other similar statements appear.

<1><40>Since there must be a basis for depositing habitual tendencies, what is this basis? According to those who accept the foundation consciousness (kun gzhi rnam shes), just as they assert the foundation consciousness—which serves as the basis that is the object of the afflicted mind's thought "I am"—to be the basis for habitual tendencies, similarly this system also asserts that the very object of the innate mind that merely thinks "I am" is the basis for depositing habitual tendencies.

<1><40>If one asks how it is that the Avatāra-commentary states that the mind-stream is the basis of habitual tendencies, [the answer is that] since the mere "I" is a continuum imputed in dependence upon mind and consciousness, it is also called a mind-stream. Moreover, if we understand it as referring to the continuum of mind itself's similar types, that too becomes the basis for imprinting occasional habitual tendencies.

<1><40>Regarding the nature of ignorance's habitual tendencies, the Commentary on Entering the Middle Way states: "That which stains and permeates the mental continuum and causes it to follow after is a habitual tendency. The terms 'ultimate limit of afflictions,' 'habituation,' 'root,' and 'habitual tendency' are synonymous. Even though afflictions have been abandoned through the uncontaminated path, śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas cannot abandon these tendencies. This is like how even when sesame oil and flowers have been removed, subtle traces remain observable in vessels and cloth that contacted them."

<1><40>The principle of two bases should be appropriately applied to other habitual tendencies as well, such as those of virtue and non-virtue. One might object: "At the time of the uninterrupted path of the path of seeing, although the objects to be abandoned through seeing no longer exist, the latent tendencies to be abandoned through meditation must still exist. At that time, since mental consciousness is uncontaminated and not corrupted by habitual tendencies of dualistic delusive appearances, these latent tendencies cannot reasonably exist in its nature. Since sense consciousnesses are not present as their basis, and form cannot reasonably serve as their basis, and since the foundation consciousness is not accepted, there would be no basis for them." There is no fault in this, because at that time, the mere 'I' serves as the basis for the latent tendencies to be abandoned through meditation. This should be understood similarly for other objects of abandonment and their antidotes. If one understands this system's unique way of positing the person, one can address objections such as: "When transcendent uncontaminated mind manifests in the continuum of noble ones born in the three realms of infinite space, infinite consciousness, and nothingness, their existence would cease since no other worldly mind exists."

<1><40>When an undefiled mind belonging to the level of Nothingness manifests in an Ārya born in the Peak of Existence, the beings included in both the Peak of Existence and Nothingness realms would cease, because that undefiled mind's abode is not suitable as either of those two destinies or the destiny of nirvāṇa. These arguments appear not to invalidate [our position], because even without positing either defiled or undefiled minds as the defining characteristics of those destinies, it is sufficient to establish destinies. The opponent's position maintains that the nature of destinies of those who have not entered the path and trainees is unobstructed and neutral. How could someone like me independently express such responses regarding the great systems? However, I have spoken based on the systems of the great charioteers who know how to fully establish Protector Nāgārjuna's intention exactly as it is. Based on these, it appears that the remaining arguments proving store-consciousness also do not invalidate this system. This should be investigated by those of great, subtle, and sharp intelligence.

<1><41>Second: Explaining through an example that very meaning previously explained about effects arising from ceased actions: Just as when a fool, having seen objects of perception such as a beautiful woman in a dream, even after waking up - that is, even at the time of being awake - develops strong attachment by focusing on what has now ceased and is non-existent, similarly, even from actions that have ceased and do not inherently exist, effects of actions do arise. This shows that effects arise from disintegrated actions.

<1><41>As evidence for this, from the Sūtra on the Transference of Existence: "Great King, it is thus: for example, if a man in his sleep dreams of having relations with a beautiful woman of his region, and upon waking from sleep remembers that beautiful woman of the region, Great King, what do you think? Would that man who dreamed of having relations with the beautiful woman of the region and who, upon waking from sleep, remembers that beautiful woman, be one of wise nature?" He responded, "No, Blessed One. Why is that? Blessed One, since the beautiful woman in the dream does not exist and cannot be observed, how could there be relations with her? Indeed, such a man would become one with a destiny of misery and exhaustion." This is the citation of the example.

<1><41>Connecting this to the meaning: Great King, likewise, childish ordinary beings who lack learning, having seen forms with their eyes, manifestly become attached to forms that make the mind happy. Having become manifestly attached, they generate attachment. Having become attached, they perform actions with body, speech and mind that arise from desire, arise from anger, and arise from delusion.

<1><41>When that action has become manifestly conditioned, it ceases. When it has ceased, it does not abide depending on the eastern direction, and up through "nor in the intermediate directions" is stated. And "not possessing learning" means not having realization of suchness from hearing teachings that explain suchness.
<1><41>Manifest clinging is clinging to truth.

<1><41>Regarding the three actions arising from attachment, they comprise both virtuous and non-virtuous actions. Actions arising from hatred are non-virtuous, and concerning those arising from delusion, there exists accumulation of both types of actions.

<1><41>The immediate cessation of actions after being performed is conventional, while the remainder refutes inherently established cessation. Then, at some other time when the moment of death approaches, when the propelling karma that is commensurate with that [being's fortune] is exhausted and the final consciousness ceases, it is thus: just as one who has awakened from sleep turns their mind toward a beautiful woman from their dream realm, the mind turns toward that very karma. This means when the karma maintaining the same-type aggregates in this life is exhausted and this life's final consciousness ceases, just as a person with desire immediately recalls the dream's beautiful woman upon waking and turns their mind toward her, at death the mind turns toward the awakened karmic potential that will ripen in the next life - though this is not remembering.

<1><41>Thus, when the final consciousness ceases and the first consciousness belonging to birth [arises], as stated in the passage from "whether among the gods" up to "or it will arise among the hungry ghosts," the final cessation refers to that of this life.

<1><41>Regarding the arising of the first consciousness belonging to birth, it is stated "among the gods" and so forth. Since the intermediate existence is not one of the six types of beings, it is the consciousness of birth existence. Although there is an intermediate existence between birth and death, it appears that in many cases it is not mentioned, as the intention is to establish the connection between karma and its results mainly from the perspective of birth and death. Then, immediately after that first consciousness ceases, a stream of mind arises that is similar in fortune to that which will manifestly experience the karmic ripening.

<1><41>Great King, while no phenomenon transfers from this world to the next world, there is the appearance of death-transition and birth. Great King, regarding this, the cessation of the final consciousness is called death-transition, and the arising of the first consciousness is called birth.
<1><41>Great King, when final consciousness ceases, it does not go anywhere.
<1><41>When consciousness that belongs to the category of birth arises, it does not come from anywhere whatsoever. If one asks why that is so, it is because it is devoid of inherent nature.
<1><41>Great King, the final consciousness is empty of final consciousness. Death and transmigration is empty of death and transmigration.
<1><41>Karma is empty of karma.
<1><41>The first consciousness is empty of the first consciousness.

<1><41>It is stated: "Birth is empty of birth, yet actions do not go to waste." Before connecting to a new existence through rebirth, one experiences happiness or suffering as the result of previous karma. The continuum of consciousness that experiences that arises from the first moment of birth consciousness. Death, transmigration, and birth exist conventionally but not ultimately, and the reason given is that they are devoid of intrinsic nature - this qualifies what is being negated and should be applied to the statement that the final consciousness and so forth are empty of themselves. When this is taught, fearing that people might grasp that karma and its results do not exist, it is stated that actions do not go to waste.

<1><42>The third has two parts: rejecting the objection regarding endless ripening effects and rejecting the objection that contradicts scriptures teaching the existence of the foundation consciousness.$$For the first: If one thinks there would be the fault of infinite regress - because if one accepts that ripening effects arise from actions that are not inherently produced and thus have no inherent cessation, then similarly effects would arise again even from what has already ripened - just as objects are equally non-existent yet those with eye disease see forms of non-existent floating hairs but not forms of other non-existent things like donkey horns or children of barren women, similarly understand that while actions equally lack inherent existence, ripening occurs from what has not yet ripened but does not occur again from what has already ripened.

<1><43>This example not only establishes with certainty that actions produce results, but also explains that pleasant and unpleasant results definitely arise separately from virtuous and non-virtuous actions respectively. Just as someone with diseased eyes certainly sees floating hairs and such but does not see non-existent things like donkey horns, pleasant karmic ripening cannot arise from non-virtuous actions, and unpleasant karmic ripening cannot arise from virtuous actions. Therefore, unpleasant karmic ripening, which is non-virtuous, arises from black actions...
<1><43>One sees that pleasant karmic ripening is that which arises from virtue.

<1><43>Those with the understanding that virtuous and non-virtuous actions do not exist - that is, those who realize that inherent establishment is not observed - will become liberated from samsara. Therefore, regarding those ordinary beings who analyze in detail through reasoning that establishes validity the reasons why these particular results arise from these particular actions, the Victor, thinking that conventional truth would be destroyed through denying karma and its results, declared "The ripening of the results of actions is inconceivable." Thus he discouraged thinking about, that is analysis of, karma and its results.

<1><43>Understand that this text employs many methods to generate certainty about karma and its results, out of concern that certainty about karma and its results might be lost through various approaches. With the view of emptiness also serving to strengthen that certainty, strive to ensure that your current journey to the Precious Island does not go to waste.

<1><44>The second has three parts: the actual meaning of the words that eliminate scriptural contradiction, the manner of whether foundation consciousness distinct from mental consciousness is explained or not explained, and showing examples of teachings given with specific intent.$$Regarding the first: If one can establish the relationship between karma and results without foundation consciousness, then what about the teachings in the Lankavatara Sutra and others like the Samdhinirmocana Sutra and Mahayana Abhidharma Sutra that describe foundation consciousness as the basis containing the potentials of all phenomena, the repository of all seeds, causing all inner and outer phenomena like waves arising from an ocean? This is not the case. Rather, foundation consciousness was taught to exist for those trainees who needed such teaching. This shows that in our own system, when teaching foundation consciousness as requiring interpretation, the basis of the intention - what was actually intended - is emptiness alone, the lack of inherent existence, which is indicated by the term "foundation consciousness."
<1><44>As for what is taught as the alaya (foundation consciousness), it is because that nature pervades all things.

<1><44>Not only does [the Buddha] teach the existence of the foundation consciousness for a specific purpose, but he also teaches that the person exists substantially. This is because by teaching its existence to those beings who need to be tamed, they can be guided. As stated: "O monks, the five aggregates are the burden. The bearer of the burden is the person." Thus, when responding to those who hold that the person exists as a self-sufficient substance, rather than teaching its non-existence, [the Buddha] taught that there exists a person who bears the burden. Though the term "substantial" is not explicitly stated, the meaning indicates substantial existence.

<1><44>Furthermore, to some disciples he taught mere aggregates without a substantially existent person, saying: "That which is called mind, or mental faculty, or consciousness - when thoroughly imbued with faith, moral discipline and so forth for a long time, and when progressing upward - will proceed to higher realms in the next life."

<1><44>Moreover, regarding those who hold as true the way of going to higher realms and liberation, when they wonder how much they should accept, by teaching that there are merely aggregates without refuting the object of their truth-clinging, [the Buddha] implicitly teaches the aggregates as true. All of these were taught through the power of [his] intention.

<1><44>If one asks "For which disciples was this taught with reference to?", in response it should be stated: [it was for those who hold that] the foundation consciousness exists and the person exists substantially.

<1><44>The teaching that states "these aggregates alone truly exist" was taught with consideration for those disciples who, for the time being, are unable to understand or realize such a profound meaning as previously explained.

<1><44>Because certain disciples have long been habituated to non-Buddhist views, they are unable to engage with the profound reality. As stated in the Ratnavali: "There is no self and will not be; there is no mine and will not be" - thus the childish become frightened. When reality is taught initially, they become frightened and, considering the Buddha's teaching like a precipice, they turn their backs on the teaching and do not engage with it, thus not accomplishing great purpose. For these ones, rather than teaching the ultimate profound points right at first, by teaching about alaya-vijnana and the true existence of aggregates etc., based on that, the non-Buddhist systems are eliminated and they are led to great purpose. Later, when they properly understand the meaning of the scriptures, they themselves will abandon grasping at the existence of alaya etc. Therefore, teaching in this way brings only benefits and not faults.

<1><44>Having this sequence in mind, the Śatakaśāstra states: "Whatever a person is attracted to, that very thing should be practiced first. One who has deteriorated is by no means a vessel for the sacred Dharma."

<1><44>As for those who need to be taught the alaya consciousness as being separate in essence from the six collections, since the external must be negated, they are suitable vessels for just the suchness that is empty of subject and object being different substances.

<1><44>Even though one does not accept the alayavijnana (foundation consciousness) as explained before, since one cannot establish the connection between actions and their results, it is taught that one will not understand the very profound meaning.

<1><44>Second, when teaching the enumeration of consciousnesses in many texts such as the Perfection of Wisdom in One Hundred Thousand, only six collections of consciousness are explained and nothing more is taught. Since there are many sutras that do not posit the foundation consciousness, just as there are two approaches in the sutras regarding positing or not positing the foundation consciousness, likewise when Venerable Maitreya commented on their meaning, he explained the position accepting foundation consciousness and rejecting external objects in the Madhyāntavibhāga, Mahāyānasūtrālaṃkāra, and Dharmadharmatāvibhāga, while in the Abhisamayālaṃkāra and Uttaratantra he explained the position that does not posit foundation consciousness and does not reject external objects.

<1><44>The great master Asaṅga also did not explain the intention of the Uttaratantra according to the Cittamātra system, but rather explained it according to the Madhyamaka system. And in his commentary on the Uttaratantra, regarding the Abhidharma scripture quoted in the Mahāyānasaṃgraha as proof of the ālayavijñāna, it states: "Although sentient beings have the tathāgata-dhātu which has become their essence, those sentient beings do not know it."

<1><44>As it is said: "The element of beginningless time is the abode of all phenomena. Because it exists, all beings and nirvana too are attained." This is cited as proof that sentient beings possess the disposition of dharmatā. Therefore, since this master explains the intended basis of ālayavijñāna as emptiness, he maintains that an ālaya distinct in essence from the six collections was taught for the sake of certain disciples due to necessity.

<1><44>If that is so, regarding what is stated in the Bodhicittavivaraṇa about foundation consciousness apprehending existence: "Just as iron swiftly turns when near a magnet, though lacking mind it appears as if possessing mind. Similarly, foundation consciousness, though not real, appears as if real. When it moves with coming and going, then it holds existence. Just as trees in the ocean move though mindless, likewise foundation consciousness moves in dependence on the body." How should this be interpreted? This teaching of mind-only, which rejects external objects separate from mind without negating the intrinsic existence of mind itself, was taught to dispel beginners' fear of the teaching that all is empty, and is not definitive truth. When refuting the Yogācāra assertion that transformed pure mind exists intrinsically as an object of self-cognizing awareness, there arises the implicit objection that if mind has no true existence, the movement of coming from previous lives and going to future lives would be impossible. In response, the text shows that just as iron and wood move as if having mind though mindless, similarly foundation consciousness appears to move with coming and going as if real though lacking true existence. Therefore, this does not accept foundation consciousness established by its own characteristics as explained in other texts.

<1><44>Even if one does not accept the foundation consciousness as established by its own characteristics, if one thinks "I accept an illusion-like foundation consciousness that is different in nature from the six collections and contains all seeds of both samsaric and enlightened phenomena," then in accepting such a foundation consciousness, one must accept that appearances of form, sound, and so forth are merely the ripening of habitual tendencies and that external objects do not exist. As stated in that very text: "Consciousness realizes objects of knowledge; without objects of knowledge, there is no consciousness. Therefore, why not accept that neither object nor subject exists?" This shows that external objects of knowledge and internal consciousness are equal in terms of existence or non-existence - if one doesn't exist, the other cannot exist. This aligns with what is taught here regarding objects and consciousness being equal in both their conventional existence and ultimate non-existence, making it inappropriate to distinguish between their existence or non-existence in either of the two truths. Therefore, since the master does not accept a foundation consciousness separate from mental consciousness, when speaking of "foundation consciousness," it refers generally to mind as mere awareness and clarity, and specifically to mental consciousness - because it explains how activity is possible despite mind's lack of inherent existence, because mental consciousness takes birth in existence, and because it serves as the basis for all afflicted and purified phenomena.
<1><44>In the Madhyamakahṛdaya, the literal interpretation of ālaya is refuted, and Master Jñānagarbha, because he accepts external objects, also does not accept the ālaya.

<1><44>Among the Cittamātrins who refute external objects, there appear to be two types: those who accept ālayavijñāna (foundation consciousness) and those who do not. Master Kamalaśīla, who does not accept external objects, also maintains that mental consciousness (manovijñāna) alone possesses the power to connect with another birth. As quoted from the Abhidharmakośa: "Severance and connection, freedom from attachment, deterioration, death-transition, and birth are maintained to be mental consciousness alone." This clearly demonstrates that the great master Śāntarakṣita also does not accept ālayavijñāna. Abhayākara holds the same position.

<1><44>Although in other Mahayana scriptures the term "all-ground consciousness" is mentioned, there does not appear to be any clear identification beyond merely understanding the name. When examining the meaning, it appears they only maintain that it is not distinct in essence from the six collections (of consciousness). And since that system appears to be on the side of accepting external objects, this name is applied to mental consciousness. Although these matters need to be established extensively, I have not written (more) out of fear of being too lengthy.

<1><45>Third, not only did [the Buddha] teach the foundation consciousness and so forth initially in order to guide disciples, but also, just as the Buddha Bhagavan, though free from the view of the transitory collection together with its habitual tendencies and having abandoned all conceptual thoughts that grasp at "I" and "mine," nevertheless taught expressions of "I" and "mine" as a method for worldly beings to understand the meaning of the Dharma, similarly, although things do not exist inherently, teaching that they exist inherently is taught as provisional meaning as a method for worldly beings to gradually understand suchness.

<1><45>In brief, according to what is stated as "I" and "mine", although it appears there are such conceptions, the definitive meaning is the absence of conceptions. Similarly, although the teaching that phenomena are inherently established appears to be the Buddha's intention, the definitive meaning is that phenomena do not exist in that way.

<1><45>Regarding how to engage with conventional presentations in accordance with the world, as stated in verses according to the Eastern Mountain School: If the guides of the world do not engage in accordance with the world, no one would understand what Buddha nature is and who is Buddha. While maintaining that aggregates, elements, and sense bases have one nature, they teach about the three realms - this is engaging in accordance with the world. Teaching nameless dharmas to sentient beings through inconceivable names - this is engaging in accordance with the world. While demonstrating non-existence and abiding in Buddha nature, teaching that there is no non-existence here - this is engaging in accordance with the world. Not perceiving meaning and meaninglessness, yet teaching the supreme speech of cessation and ultimate meaning - this is engaging in accordance with the world. Though there is no destruction or arising, and while equal to the dharmadhātu, teaching about the kalpa of burning - this is engaging in accordance with the world. Though the nature of sentient beings is not observed in the three times, teaching about the realm of sentient beings - this is engaging in accordance with the world. Thus it is extensively taught.

<1><45>Among these, the last verse teaches the selflessness of persons - the lack of intrinsic existence of sentient beings - and the remaining verses teach the selflessness of phenomena - the lack of intrinsic existence of things and non-things. Since the "Blaze of Reasoning" explains that the Eastern Mountain School gradually split off from the Mahāsāṃghika School, it appears there exists a Śrāvaka scriptural collection that very clearly teaches the lack of intrinsic existence of phenomena.

<1><46>Second, the specific refutation of the Cittamātra system has three parts: (1) refuting intrinsically established consciousness without external objects, (2) refuting valid cognition that proves the intrinsic establishment of dependent nature, and (3) showing that the word 'only' in the teaching of mind-only does not negate external objects. The first has two parts: presenting others' system and refuting that system. Regarding the first: The Consciousness-Only proponents, being unable to accept the Madhyamaka system as previously explained and claiming it does not represent the Buddha's intention, establish their position by expressing a system constructed through their own conceptual elaborations. To clearly present their system as explained in their own texts, the opponent's position states: The bodhisattva dwelling in and meditating on the supreme perfection of wisdom on the sixth ground realizes suchness through reasoning, without erroneously superimposing subject-object substantial duality, and realizes, sees, and comprehends this as consciousness-only suchness.

<1><46>Furthermore, because there are no external forms, mind and mental factors are understood to be merely dependently originated phenomena without external forms as their objects. Therefore, this is called the realization of suchness in terms of mere consciousness.

<1><46>If one asks how this bodhisattva realizes suchness in this way: Because this bodhisattva, through the reasoning that will be explained about forms and so forth arising from the ripening of internal habitual tendencies, sees that there is no apprehended object that is a different substance from mind, and without that, sees no apprehender that is separate from the object. Having thoroughly realized that the three realms of existence are mere consciousness, they then cultivate familiarity with the suchness of emptiness of duality for a long time. Through such familiarity, they directly perceive through self-awareness the thing that is inexpressible in words as suchness - the mere nature of emptiness of duality. Therefore, through this process of previous familiarization, the bodhisattva on the sixth ground realizes the suchness of mere consciousness.

<1><46>If these are merely cognitions without external objects, then how does mind-only bearing the aspects of external objects arise without external objects? The answer: Just as the great ocean that supports waves, when stirred and agitated by wind, transitions from its previous motionless state (as if sleeping) to waves that obtain their own form through competition and are perceived as flowing everywhere, similarly from the foundation consciousness (ālayavijñāna) - which contains seeds of all outer and inner phenomena - mere consciousness of impure dependent nature arises through the maturation of habitual tendencies. These tendencies were deposited in the foundation consciousness through the cessation of both afflictions like attachment and virtues like faith, according to their respective types. While ordinary beings conceive of this in terms of grasped and grasper divided into outer and inner, there exists not even the slightest object that is substantially different from consciousness.

<1><47>This is like how those who assert Ishvara and others as causes say: "Just as a spider is the cause of spider webs, crystal is like [the cause] of waters, and bilanga is like [the cause] of branches, that [Ishvara] is the cause of all embodied beings." Just as those who speak of Ishvara and others as the agent of beings [say this], the proponents of alayavijnana also assert that it possesses all seeds by virtue of being the support of all objects that are observed by consciousness.

<1><47>The difference is this: Īśvara is permanent while the ālayavijñāna is impermanent. Therefore, those who have become habituated to tīrthika views through many previous lifetimes are to be tamed through the explanation of the ālaya.

<1><47>The meaning of the term "proponents of internal objects of knowledge" is that objects of knowledge are form, sound, and so forth, and these are not asserted to be external but rather are propounded to be internal entities of consciousness.

<1><47>If the Cittamātrins accept form, sound, and so forth, then refuting their external nature would become merely arguing about names, because they posit these very forms and so forth that appear as external as being external. When this objection is raised, it is similar to saying that when Mādhyamikas refute intrinsic establishment of form and so forth while positing form and so forth, they are positing these very forms and so forth that appear to be intrinsically established as being intrinsically established. Therefore, arguing about their existence or non-existence is merely arguing about names. Since this appears to be a major difficult point for both philosophical systems, not only is the Madhyamaka approach difficult, but in this Cittamātra system as well, it is evident that if external objects are refuted, form and so forth would become non-existent, and if form and so forth are posited, external objects would also need to be posited. Although these points are difficult, I have not written more, fearing lengthiness.

<1><48>Because the presentation of the scriptures is well-known to be as previously explained, therefore one must necessarily accept this which is the intrinsically established nature of the dependent nature. This is because it is accepted to be the cause and basis for the entire network of conceptual thoughts, such as grasping at the imputed existence of apprehended and apprehender things as substantially distinct.
<1><48>The mistaken perception of a snake that has a rope as its basis cannot arise where there is no rope as its ground.

<1><48>Just as illusions that are based on causes such as vases do not arise in regions of space that are without earth and so forth, similarly, if external objects do not exist, what kind of cause could there be for the conceptual misconception that misconceives blue and so forth as external? Therefore, one must necessarily accept the impure dependent nature that appears as dual apprehended-apprehender that are substantially different as the cause of the conceptual misconception that misconceives things as external, because that very basis of appearance is the cause of both bondage and liberation of affliction and purity.

<1><48>According to both Madhyamaka and Cittamatra systems, when there exists a teaching showing that the basis of clinging—that which appears to sentient beings and to which they cling as truly existing in accordance with its appearance—is empty of its conceived object, then realizing such emptiness becomes the path. However, if instead of taking as the path the realization of emptiness that negates what ordinary beings cling to as truly existing, one establishes some other emptiness as truly existing, this cannot serve as an antidote to any subtle or coarse clinging to true existence that has existed since beginningless time, making such effort fruitless.

<1><48>Thus, regarding the dependent nature that appears as duality, where subject and object appear as substantially distinct: the imagined nature that is the object of grasping at their existence as they appear does not exist. One correctly sees that this basis is empty of that object of negation. And that which remains here - the basis of emptiness and the emptiness itself - truly exists here. Through understanding this exactly as it is, one will come to excellently grasp the meaning of emptiness.

<1><48>Here, what is presented as the prior position is the explanation from the Bodhisattvabhūmi and Madhyāntavibhāgaṭīkā of the meaning of "whatever is not in whatever" as explained above. As for the explanation of the meaning of "whatever is not in whatever" in the Uttaratantra commentary, it exists as a Madhyamaka way of explanation completely unlike the previous two, but I have not written it out for fear of being too lengthy.
<1><48>That dependent nature arises from its own habitual tendencies alone, without external apprehended objects.

<1><48>It exists inherently, and according to this system, it exists as having a nature that is ultimate and not the object of any elaborations of words and thoughts, because external and internal verbal expressions grasp the unanalyzed aspect.
<1><48>In brief, the dependent nature has three distinguishing features: it arises without external objects, it exists by its own nature, and it is not an object of ultimate elaborations.
<1><48>Since that which is to be analyzed is included within the category of inherently existent entities, it is not distinct from the three characteristics.

<1><48>The statement that "dependent nature exists" does not mean mere existence, but rather a qualified existence. As Master Sthiramati states: "Unreal conceptualization exists," and "by its own nature" is the remainder of the statement. Since this is so, understanding this qualification becomes important later.

<1><49>The second has two parts: an extensive explanation of the refutation and a concluding summary of that refutation. The first has three parts: (1) refuting the example of intrinsically established consciousness without external objects, (2) refuting the point that consciousness empty of objects arises from the power of latent tendencies, and (3) demonstrating that this refutation does not contradict meditation on unattractiveness. The first has two parts: refuting the dream example and refuting the example of seeing falling hairs. The first has three parts: (1) showing the dream example does not establish consciousness as intrinsically existent, (2) showing the dream example does not establish the absence of external objects during waking states, and (3) showing the dream example establishes all things as false. Regarding the first: If you Cittamātrins assert that external objects don't exist but mind exists through its own characteristics, where is your example for this? This must be examined.

<1><49>The Cittamātra says: "For example, while sleeping in a very small room and being overcome by sleep, the elephants from a dreamed herd of mad elephants cannot exist in that room in any way. Therefore, just as in a dream, while external objects do not exist, this intrinsically established consciousness must definitely be accepted." To show that this too is without essence, it is explained: "That very example should be considered here - that is, analyzed."

<1><49>What is to be examined? Just as there are no elephants as objects [in dreams], in my system there exists no mind that has the appearance of a herd of intoxicated cattle and is established by its own characteristics even in dreams, because it is unborn.

<1><49>If consciousness is not established by its own characteristics, then at that time your example is not established for both parties; therefore, consciousness cannot exist without external objects.

<1><49>Here, it is not teaching that consciousness qua subject does not exist just as an elephant appearing in a dream does not exist. Rather, one must definitely accept that it teaches the nonexistence of intrinsically established consciousness. This is because, as previously explained, the Cittamatra's acceptance of the dependent nature that lacks external objects is based on the dependent nature being intrinsically established. And in summarizing these refutations, when commenting on "In brief, just as there is no object of knowledge, there is no consciousness," it is clearly stated that consciousness possessing the aspects of objects of knowledge is not produced by its own nature.

<1><49>Moreover, when refuting such types in both the root text and commentary, because there are many qualifications applied to the object of negation, and because it is also this system's own position when the great master states "Why did they teach that mind arises from ignorance and karma?" - that ignorance produces karmic formations and karmic formations produce consciousness - there is no basis for doubt among the discerning regarding claims that this system holds consciousness to be non-existent. Therefore, all instances of drawing equivalence between existence and non-existence with respect to objects of knowledge and consciousness should be understood from the perspective of the qualifications of the object of negation.

<1><50>"If there is no mistaken consciousness in dreams, then upon waking one would not later remember the experiences from the time of the dream" - if one thinks this, this is an argument based on the assumption that if consciousness is not established by its own essence, then consciousness is completely nonexistent.

<1><50>This argument is also not acceptable. If the mind of dreams were established by its own nature based on remembering the experience of dreams upon awakening, then external objects appearing in dreams, such as elephants, would also exist in the same way as that mind. Why? Just as you have a memory of the subject thinking "I saw during dream time" when awake, similarly since there is memory of experiencing objects thinking "I saw this object" at the time of dreaming regarding external objects, you must accept either that the objects exist or that consciousness also does not exist.

<1><50>Well then, since memories of both the object and subject of dreams exist even in our own system, how should we understand their existence and non-existence? Here, the Commentary explains two things: memory of the dream experience and memory of experiencing the objects of the dream. When an elephant and so forth appears during a dream, for example, just as when seeing a reflection in a mirror, although the visual consciousness that perceives the reflection does not experience the mirror itself, there is still an experience of the object in relation to the reflection. Similarly, although there is no experience of an elephant during the dream, there is an experience of the object that appears. So even though we speak of "remembering the object," what is remembered is the experience of that object.

<1><50>Differentiating between objects of perception and experience is unnecessary in many such cases, except for some occasions. Thus, a dependent nature that is empty of external objects and established by its own characteristics cannot be posited, because not only is a direct example impossible, but unlike the case of proving the existence of past and future lives where, although there is no direct example, it can be proved through other methods of logical formulation, there is no such example in this case either. Therefore, one should understand that the reasoning refuting the Cittamātra is extremely powerful.

<1><51>As for the second point: If forms of elephants and so forth exist in dreams, then the visual consciousness that apprehends them would also have to exist in dreams. However, this is not reasonable, because when one is asleep, visual consciousness (that is, visual awareness) is impossible due to being disturbed by sleep. Therefore, forms such as elephants and so forth cannot be apprehended by the eye sense-sphere, and only mental consciousness exists. Thus, external form sense-spheres definitely do not exist, and when aspects of those external objects appear in mental consciousness, one unavoidably conceives of them as being external.

<1><51>If one says that just as consciousness alone arises without external objects in dreams, so it is asserted to be in this waking state - this means that even if that previous example is not established, the dream example establishes consciousness without external objects in the waking state. This is not so, because it is impossible for mental consciousness to arise in dreams. What is stated here means that even if we grant there are no visual form-fields in dreams, mental consciousness inherently established without those is impossible even in dreams. Therefore, the combination of the absence of external objects and the inherent existence of mental consciousness is not suitable as an example.

<1><52>Just as according to you external objects are not born in dreams, likewise mental consciousness too is not produced by its own nature. Therefore, just as when awake and seeing form, the three - eye, form and mind - come together, likewise when comprehending objects in dreams too, the coming together of the three is observed by the intellect.

<1><52>Just as in a dream there are no eyes and visual forms, likewise the visual consciousness that is produced by these two also does not exist. Therefore, all three - the dream eyes, forms, and mental faculty - are false.
<1><53>Similarly to those three, the remaining three [sense faculties] of the ear and so forth beyond those three of the eye also lack inherent production.

<1><53>Here, the term "and so on" includes everything from sound and ear consciousness up through mind, dharma-element, and mental consciousness. As explained, the four from ear faculty through body faculty, the four from sound through tactile sources, and the four including ear consciousness and others are, like the three aspects of eye previously explained, false because although they do not exist in dreams, they appear as their aspects. The three mental factors, though present in dreams, are false because they appear while lacking inherent existence. Therefore, those who claim this master's position includes the existence of sense consciousness in dreams and then refute it demonstrate extremely crude understanding. As is said, "The sun of refutation rises before the dawn of the opponent's position" - such approaches should be thoroughly rejected. Some who pride themselves as Tibetan scholars fail to understand even the basic systems of those they know, yet make them objects for accumulating negative karma and lead many beings toward non-virtue. Be vigilant about this!

<1><53>Here, when the Cittamātrins establish their own system as explained in the statement beginning "If in sleep...", Master Bhaviveka responds that the example is not established, saying: "In dreams, there exists a form belonging to the dharma-āyatana that is to be apprehended by mental consciousness; therefore, consciousness never exists without an object." Regarding this, his position too is incorrect because the three components cannot possibly exist in any aspect within dreams. If one accepts this merely to refute the opponent's system, then the dream example becomes meaningless, because if it had non-false content, it could not demonstrate that the actual meaning derived from the example has false content. The meaning of this statement is that the three elements - object, sense faculty, and consciousness - cannot possibly exist by way of their own nature in any aspect, even in dreams.

<1><53>It should be explained that it is not reasonable for there to be an object other than consciousness of form in the domain of mental phenomena in dreams. At that time, one must also accept that form itself, and it is not contradictory for that to exist in dreams as well. Therefore, since it is clear that Bhāviveka accepts that form as established by its own characteristics, this should be taken as the reason for its non-existence.

<1><53>If one accepts that form exists through its own characteristics in order to refute the Cittamātra position (which uses dreams as an example to show that there are no external form objects belonging to the external sense spheres), then at that time there would be no purpose in the Mādhyamika presenting the dream example to prove the lack of true existence.

<1><53>The dream has meaningful content that is not false, because it is established by its own characteristics as arising from the example. It is impossible for the actual object that is exemplified by that to be established as false, because until intrinsic existence is refuted, there is no pervasion of the sign, property and example that establishes the lack of true existence. Therefore, the earlier response from our own system that all appearances in dreams are not intrinsically established is excellent.

<1><53>If asked whether according to our own system the forms that appear clearly in dreams are accepted as dharma-āyatana forms or not: Since there are no sense consciousnesses in dreams, what appear as the five objects appear only to mental consciousness. Therefore, although the five sense sources such as form cannot be posited there, just as the clear appearance of a skeleton to mind alone is included as a dharma-āyatana, they are dharma-āyatana forms. Moreover, among its five forms, they are imputed forms. Through this, many such cases should be understood.

<1><53>Third: Because all three - what appear as objects, sense faculties, and consciousness in dreams - are unreal, therefore, in order to establish those phenomena that have not yet been established as lacking true existence through the means of establishing that dreams lack true existence, it is explained that even when awake, all phenomena will be established as lacking inherent nature.

<1><53>Just as objects, sense faculties, and consciousnesses in dreams are false, likewise here in the waking state too, all things are false. Therefore, the mind does not exist inherently. Similarly, the objects of the sense faculties such as forms and so forth do not exist, and the sense faculties themselves do not arise inherently. Therefore, as stated in the sūtra: "Just as illusory beings are perceived, though they appear, they are not real in ultimate reality. The Sugata taught that phenomena are like illusions and dreams." And: "The beings of existence are like dreams - here no one is born or dies. No sentient being, human, or life force can be found. These phenomena are like bubbles and plantain trees." Thus it is well explained.

<1><53>The phrase "no one is born" and so forth should be applied with the qualification "in reality" as used in the phrase "in reality, not real" when making a negation. These sutras explain through the example of dreams that all phenomena are not established in reality - this works for Madhyamaka but does not work for Cittamatra, therefore it is said to become a good explanation.

<1><54>Therefore, in this world, although there exists the sleep of ignorance, for some who are awake by being free from ordinary sleep that is distinct from that [ignorance], although nothing arises through its own nature, within the perspective of what appears in dreams due to the sleep of ignorance, all three exist. Similarly, for those who are not free from sleep and not awake, as long as that state continues, for them - that is, from their perspective - the three factors of object, sense faculty, and consciousness also exist.

<1><54>When awakening from sleep, just as the three aspects of a dream do not exist, likewise for the Buddhas who have directly realized the dharmadhātu through completely exhausting and eradicating the sleep of ignorance, since none of the three aspects exist, there is no consciousness without external objects.

<1><54>Furthermore, from the perspective of seeing things as they are, the three do not appear. And from the perspective of seeing things in their full extent, although there is no appearance due to the power of the subject itself being corrupted by the latent tendencies of ignorance, the Buddha knows those things that appear due to the power of other beings' corrupted consciousness through their appearing to those beings.

<1><55>Second: If one objects, "Since those with eye disease perceive nonexistent floating hairs and so forth, consciousness must exist inherently even though external objects do not exist," that too is untenable.

<1><55>Why is this? When someone whose eye faculty is affected by a visual disorder sees hair-like shapes through the power of that disorder, then from the perspective of that person's consciousness, both the visual consciousness and the aspect of the hair-like shapes—that is, the object appearing as hair-like shapes—exist.

<1><55>From the perspective of clear vision - that is, seeing with eyes free from eye disease - both the appearance of hair strands and the consciousness that perceives that appearance are false, meaning unborn, because it is difficult to ascertain that consciousness exists without even a merely appearing object. This must definitely be accepted as such.

<1><56>That is not so. If, for someone with eye disease, there were to arise a naturally established cognition having the aspect of floating hair despite there being no floating hair to be cognized, then wherever that person with eye disease sees floating hair, even someone whose eye is directed at that same place but who lacks eye disease would develop a cognition seeing floating hair, just like the person with eye disease, because both are equal in lacking an object.

<1><56>Just as if something inherently established were to arise from another, it would follow that it would arise from everything that is other, similarly if an inherently established consciousness were to arise, given that the object (floating hair) is equally non-existent for both, it would be inconsistent that the perception of it arises in one with eye disease but does not arise in one without eye disease, because that consciousness, being able to be established without depending on the eye disease, would become unrelated.

<1><56>Since it is not the case that a cognition perceiving floating hairs arises in those without eye disease, therefore there is no consciousness that is inherently established without external objects.

<1><57>The second has three parts: (1) refuting that consciousness perceiving objects arises and does not arise from ripened and unripened habitual tendencies; (2) refuting the restatement of how consciousness exists without external objects; and (3) showing there is no scriptural contradiction in refuting the Cittamātra system. The first has two parts: stating others' position and refuting that position. Regarding the first: If the existence of objects like appearing hairs were the cause of consciousness arising, then even those without eye disease would see appearing hairs, but this is not the case. What then? The ripening and non-ripening of previously established habitual tendencies are the causes of consciousness arising and not arising. Therefore, only those individuals who have ripened habitual tendencies established by previous consciousness having the aspect of hairs will experience consciousness having the aspect of hairs.

<1><57>If one argues: Because those without eye disease have not ripened the habitual patterns that are the potential of the mind which appears as floating hairs when seeing objects, therefore those without eye disease do not develop the cognition that sees floating hairs - it is not that such cognition does not arise due to the absence of the actual thing that exists as a knowable object in the form of floating hairs.

<1><57>The second has three parts: refuting inherently established power in the present, refuting inherently established power in the future, and refuting inherently established power in the past. First: If there were something called "power" that was inherently established, then at that time, although one might allow for consciousness arising or not arising from the ripening or non-ripening of that power, since that inherently established power does not exist, this is not established.

<1><58>How is it not established? When examining this potential, would it be something connected with present consciousness, or would it become something connected with past and future consciousness? Regarding that, first, there is no possibility of an inherently established potential in what has arisen - that is, the present. Nor is there any potential in the nature of what has not arisen - the future.

<1><58>Regarding this: if one asserts that potential exists in present consciousness, both consciousness and potential would become simultaneous. At that time, when the relationship between potential and potential-possessor is expressed by the sixth case as "consciousness of potential," since these two cannot be separate entities, it is not reasonable for the consciousness of potential to exist as the potential itself. If it did exist that way, the effect would become something without any cause other than itself, and even when the sprout has arisen, the seed would not disintegrate.

<1><58>When there is the fifth case relationship between potential and that which has potential, expressed as "consciousness from potential," it is not reasonable for consciousness that has arisen to arise from a potential that is simultaneous with it, because the effect would exist at the time of the cause. Therefore, for now, there is no causal potential for present consciousness.

<1><58>As for the second: If there exists potential in unborn consciousness, then when applying the phrase "potential of consciousness," potential is the basis of qualification and consciousness is the qualifying property. Regarding that, future unborn consciousness cannot be taught as having the nature of an affirmative statement "it is consciousness," nor can it be taught as having the nature of a negation established by its own nature saying "it is not consciousness."
<1><58>When future consciousness does not exist as present consciousness, what could distinguish the potential saying "this potential is the potential of this consciousness"? It cannot.

<1><58>Thus, without a distinguishing consciousness, there cannot exist a capacity that has been qualified by it. If it were not so, it would absurdly follow that even a barren woman's son would have such a capacity.

<1><59>If a consciousness arises from potential, thinking about this, one might say "this is the potential of this consciousness and from this potential this consciousness will arise," thus establishing them as qualifier and qualified. Just as in the world when one says "Cook the rice!" or "Weave cloth from this thread!" thinking of the future rice and cloth, and just as in the Treasury where it states "There are three types of womb entry: the universal monarch and the two self-arising ones," speaking of those who will become universal monarchs entering the womb, similarly one might claim to designate the potential of consciousness while thinking of future consciousness. However, this is meaningless. If something exists occasionally, its effect will arise later, but that which never arises at any time - like a barren woman's son or unconditioned space - will not arise either now or later. Therefore, even if one accepts consciousness arising when there is inherently established potential, since future consciousness does not inherently exist at any time, there is absolutely no potential to produce it. Thus, like a barren woman's son, without inherently established potential to produce consciousness, no inherently established consciousness can arise.

<1><59>When Madhyamikas refute the establishment of a sprout's arising through its own characteristics in many contexts, they present the following extreme consequence: "If a sprout can arise despite not existing at the time of the seed, then rabbit horns and such would also arise." The key point of presenting such an extreme consequence is that if a sprout established by its own characteristics does not exist at one point, it must never exist at any time, thus becoming equivalent to something utterly nonexistent. This is not meant to refute the general principle that something can arise despite not existing previously. This same reasoning applies to examples like cooked rice, because if things arose inherently, even future things like cooked rice would necessarily be completely nonexistent.

<1><59>Furthermore, the potential is posited in dependence upon the existence of future consciousness, and if consciousness is posited in dependence upon the potential, saying "consciousness arises from the potential," then they would be established through mutual dependence. If that is accepted, then the noble ones possessing supreme wisdom have taught that consciousness is not established by its own nature.

<1><59>In the commentary, relationally established things such as long-short and far-near exist as mere imputations, but are stated to lack natural establishment. Therefore, one should understand the distinctions that this is not refuting establishment in general, but rather refuting establishment through intrinsic nature. If one speaks in this way, they will come to follow our way of speaking. Thus, consciousness also has no power over the future.

<1><60>Third, now to show that there is also no power over the past, it is explained: If a consciousness that has arisen and is ceasing places a special potency of latent tendencies in the foundation consciousness for the sake of a result concordant with itself, and if future consciousness arises from the maturation of the potency of the ceased consciousness, then a different resultant consciousness would arise from the potency of something inherently established as different. Why? Because according to you, in the sequence where momentary [phenomena] with continuity arise, the earlier and later are inherently different from each other.

<1><60>Moreover, from the root gyun, regarding ta nu meaning "to expand," when the affix is added, it becomes gyun (continuum) through transmission. Like the flow of a river, when causes and effects operate in continuous connection, the process of birth and death continues without gaps or interruption. This refers to the conditioned phenomena that are momentary appropriators of the three times. The moments are parts of a whole, not merely an uninterrupted sequence of before and after. Since the momentary substances that are parts of the continuum exist within it, the momentary substances that are members of the continuum are called "possessors of continuum." Because the parts and members belong to that continuum, the continuum is called their "appropriator," just as a pot is the appropriator of its lip, neck, and so forth.

<1><60>Those earlier and later moments are mutually different and distinct from each other, and the opponent accepts them as being different by way of being established by their own characteristics. Thus, something arises from the power of another that is established by its own nature.
<1><60>If you think "it is not a fault because it is desired," therefore all things would arise from all other things different from themselves.

<1><61>Even though in the sequential functioning of earlier and later moments, the momentary substantial entities of the continuum are different from each other through inherent establishment, nevertheless, regarding those earlier and later moments, the continuum has no difference - it is exclusively one. Therefore, you may say there is no fault of everything arising from everything. [In response:] This [claim that] earlier and later [moments] are one continuum is the main response attempting to avoid the extreme consequence in other-arising.

<1><61>If a single continuum were established for inherently established separate entities of before and after, even if we accept there would be no fault, this single continuum is not established, therefore this single continuum is something to be proven. Why? Because it is not reasonable for there to be an undifferentiated continuum for those that are inherently established as different before and after. For example, just as those belonging to the continuums of Maitreya and Upagupta, being different individuals, are not included in a single continuum, similarly, those before and after that are established by their own characteristics as separate cannot reasonably be included in a single continuum. Thus, this addresses the fault of the extreme consequence charged against other-arising.

<1><62>When they say "Since rice seeds and sprouts are of one continuum but barley sprouts are not of the same continuum, everything does not arise from everything," they cannot avoid the flaw. The key point is that the opponent accepts otherness that is established by own-characteristics. While it is extremely clear this is not directed at mere otherness, some make arguments about shared exclusions without understanding the qualification "otherness established by own-characteristics." By leaving aside Candrakīrti's own explanation of why the opponent cannot avoid the flaw and fabricating explanations he did not give, they corrupt the perfect philosophical system.

<1><63>The second has two parts: stating others' system and refuting that system. First: Having presented their position thus far, and thinking they would accomplish their desired aim primarily by stating their own system again, the Cittamātrins said: When other consciousnesses are in the process of ceasing, they immediately deposit in the ālayavijñāna whatever habitual tendencies that are their own potential for producing eye consciousness. Later, from the ripening of those tendencies, an eye consciousness arises that follows the aspect of that previous consciousness.

<1><63>That which serves as the basis - the uninterrupted moment of potentiality from which one's eye consciousness arises from an uninterrupted moment of potentiality - is what worldly beings, due to ignorance, understand to be the physical eye faculty. However, there exists no eye faculty that is separate from consciousness. This should likewise be applied to the remaining physical sense faculties.
<1><63>Regarding that, the latent tendencies that are the cause of the arising of eye consciousness are its causal condition, and the eye faculty is the dominant condition of eye consciousness.

<1><63>Here, teaching that the eye faculty is the direct cause of visual consciousness refers to the occasion when the latent tendencies for the arising of visual consciousness have matured, not to whatever eye faculty there might be.

<1><63>Furthermore, from the Madhyāntavibhāga: "Consciousness manifesting as appearances of objects, sentient beings, and self arises abundantly, but those objects do not exist." This statement that consciousness arises appearing as objects such as form and as the five sense faculties of sentient beings refers to the foundation consciousness (ālayavijñāna). And since Master Sthiramati also explained the physical sense faculties as objects of the foundation consciousness, those Cittamātrins who accept the foundation consciousness assert that what appears as physical sense faculties to the foundation consciousness are the eye faculty and so forth.

<1><64>Having shown that there are no sense faculties such as the eye faculty that are separate from consciousness, in order to show that forms too do not exist as separate objects from consciousness, it is said: In this world, the five types of consciousness that arise from the five sense faculties, without there being external objects to be grasped such as blue and so forth, arise as appearances of blue and so forth from the ripening of seeds deposited in the alaya consciousness itself. Not understanding this, ordinary beings cling to the appearances of blue and so forth in their mind as external objects to be grasped.

books.title: དགོངས་པ་རབ་གསལ་ལས་སེམས་བསྐྱེད་དྲུག་པ། ཤོ་ལོ་ཀ ༡ ནས་ ༦༤
content:
<1><1>དགོངས་པ་རབ་གསལ་ལས་སེམས་བསྐྱེད་དྲུག་པ། ཤོ་ལོ་ཀ ༡-༦༤
<1><2>གཉིས་པ་ས་དྲུག་པ་མངོན་དུ་གྱུར་པ་བཤད་པ་ལ་བཞི། སའི་ངེས་ཚིག་དང་ཤེར་ཕྱིན་ལྷག་པར་བསྟན་པ། ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕར་ཕྱིན་གྱི་བསྔགས་པ། ཟབ་མོ་རྟེན་འབྱུང་གཟིགས་པའི་དེ་ཁོ་ན་ཉིད་བཤད་པ། སའི་ཡོན་ཏན་བརྗོད་པའི་སྒོ་ནས་མཇུག་བསྡུ་བའོ། །
<1><2>དང་པོ་ནི།ས་ལྔ་པར་བསམ་གཏན་གྱི་ཕར་ཕྱིན་ཡོངས་སུ་དག་པ་ཐོབ་པས། ས་དྲུག་པ་མངོན་དུ་ཕྱོགས་པ་སྟེ་གྱུར་པར་མཉམ་པར་བཞག་པའི་སེམས་ཕུལ་དུ་བྱུང་བ་ལ་གནས་ཏེ། དེ་ལ་བརྟེན་ནས་རྟེན་ཅིང་འབྲེལ་པར་འབྱུང་བ་རྐྱེན་ཉིད་འདི་པ་ཙམ་གྱི་ཟབ་མོའི་དེ་ཁོ་ན་ཉིད་མཐོང་བའི་བྱང་སེམས་ས་དྲུག་པ་ལ་གནས་པས་ནི། ཤེས་རབ་ཀྱི་ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ་ཕུལ་དུ་བྱུང་བ་ལ་གནས་པས་འགོག་པ་ཐོབ་པར་འགྱུར་གྱི། དེའི་སྔ་རོལ་ས་ལྔ་པ་སོགས་སུ་ནི་འགོག་པ་ཐོབ་པ་མིན་ཏེ། ཤེར་ཕྱིན་ཕུལ་དུ་བྱུང་བའི་ལྷག་པ་མེད་པའི་ཕྱིར་ཏེ། སྦྱིན་སོགས་ཀྱི་ཕར་ཕྱིན་ལྔ་ཕུལ་དུ་བྱུང་བ་ཙམ་གྱིས་ནི་འགོག་པ་ཐོབ་པར་མི་ནུས་སོ། །
<1><2>དེ་ལྟར་ཤེས་རབ་ལྷག་པའི་སྒོ་ནས་གཟུགས་བརྙན་དང་འདྲ་བའི་ཆོས་ཉིད་མངོན་དུ་གྱུར་པའི་ཕྱིར་དང་། ས་ལྔ་པར་ལམ་གྱི་བདེན་པ་ལ་དམིགས་པའི་ཕྱིར་དང་། རྫོགས་པའི་སངས་རྒྱས་ཀྱི་ཆོས་འཐོབ་པ་ལ་མངོན་དུ་ཕྱོགས་པའི་ཕྱིར། ས་འདི་ལ་མངོན་དུ་གྱུར་བ་ཞེས་བྱའོ། །
